scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 6/17/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed a diner in Emeryville, California, United States frequented by police officers.  Three people were slightly injured and it is unknown if the diner sustained any damages.
target1: Emeryville Police Officers frequenting a local diner
addnotes: The pipe bombs exploded during the early morning.  Police frequented the diner twenty-four hours a day.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 6/18/1970: Two unidentified White youths set off four firebombs around the New York University campus in Manhattan, New York, United States.  One firebomb was discovered under a car.  Another firebomb damaged a construction shanty at Tish Hall.  The third firebomb ignited under a crane and the final firebomb exploded in a trash can.  Neither of the last two firebombs did any damage.  There were no casualties.
target1: Car, construction sites, trash can in the vicinity of New York University
propcomment: Construction shanty sustained heavy damage
addnotes: The two perpetrators were described as 'clean cut' and not 'hippie types.'
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "3 Firebombs Explode Near N.Y.U. in 'Village,'" New York Times, June 18, 1970.
scite3: Homer Bigart, "Fire Truck Is Fire-Bombed During Blaze in Tenement," New York Times, June 19, 1970.

summary: 6/18/1970: While New York City Firemen were fighting a blaze in a Manhattan, United States tenement, an unknown perpetrator threw a Molotov cocktail into the hose bed of the fire truck.  The attack injured one fireman and another fireman suffered a heart attack.  Officials were unsure whether the fire at the tenement was set to trap the firemen or if the truck was attacked because it was a 'target of opportunity.'
addnotes: Fireman Sam Panasci injured himself while trying to extinguish the incendiary and fireman Waverly Howard suffered a heart attack during the incident.  It is unknown whether the fire truck sustained damages.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Homer Bigart, "Fire Truck Is Fire-Bombed During Blaze in Tenement," New York Times, June 19, 1970.

summary: 6/19/1970: Bruce Sharp and William Redwine, both African Americans, shot and killed Police Officer Kenneth Kaner as he was sitting in his squad car in Chicago Illinois, United States.
motive: African American opposition to the police
weapdetail: .12 gauge double barreled shotgun; .38 caliber revolver
addnotes: Bruce Sharp and William Redwine and three others driving in the same car noticed Officer Kenneth Kaner sitting in his car and someone in the group shouted "let's get him" and/or "let's get his gun."
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Jody P. Weiss, State of Illinois, Prisoner Review Board, "Murdered Chicago Police Officer Kenneth Kaner on June 19, 1970." Illinois Department of Corrections, August 11, 2008.
scite3: "Races: Ambushes in Chicago," Time Magazine, August 24, 1970.

summary: 6/19/1970: Police Officer Richard Radetich was shot and killed by an unknown perpetrator in San Francisco, California, United States.  While writing a ticket, a gunman pulled up to Officer Radetich in his car and shot him three times with a revolver.  The perpetrator immediately drove away.
motive: To kill police
addnotes: Police originally arrested Joe Allen Johnson for the murder but released him due to lack of evidence.  The Zodiac killer is also believed to claim credit for this attack, but the authorities did not believe this was credible.  In 1970, there were two other police officers murdered by suspected Black Nationalists in Northern California while they were making traffic stops (197008060004 and 197008200003).
scite1: Jim Herron Zamora, "1967-71: a Bloody Period For S.F. Police," San Francisco Chronicle, January 27, 2001.
scite2: "Chicago, Coast Policemen Shot,"  Baltimore Sun, June 20, 1970.
scite3: "Young Policeman Slain In Berkeley," New York Times, August 21, 1970.

summary: 6/21/1970: Suspected members of the Black Panther Party are believed to have set a booby-trap package underneath a bridge in Iowa, United States, intended to kill Des Moines Police Officers.  An anonymous caller tipped the police about the package.  When the police arrived, it only failed to explode due to a sliver of wood blocking the trigger.
target1: Des Moines Police responding to an anonymous phone call
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: Two-and-one-half by sixteen inch sticks of dynamite along with nuts, bolts, nails, and metal brushes connected to a battery
addnotes: On May 5th 1970, a large quantity of dynamite was stolen from Quick Supply, a dynamite supply warehouse in Ankeny Iowa.  Police believed that the stolen dynamite was used by the Black Panthers in this attack as well as in four other incidents taking place in Iowa during May and June 1970 (197005130001, 197005220003, 197006130001, and 197006290001).
scite1: Committee on Internal Security House of Representatives, "Black Panther Party, Part 4," U.S. Government Printing Office, October-November, 1970.
scite2: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite3: "Wood Sliver Saves Police From Bomb," Washington Post, June 23. 1970.

summary: 6/23/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed a bomb at a U.S. Air Force recruiting Station in San Francisco, California, United States.  The bomb was discovered by a station employee and subsequently removed.
target1: U.S. Air Force Recruiting Station, San Francisco
motive: To protest the Vietnam War and the draft
weapdetail: The bomb consisted of a plastic bottle and lead pipe filled with dynamite and connected to a clock
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Team Defuses Planted Bomb," The Modesto Bee, June 23, 1970.

summary: 6/25/1970: Fred Loyd Hayes bombed a house purchased by an African American woman in a White neighborhood in Longview, Texas, United States.  There were no casualties and it is unknown what damages the house sustained.

motive: To protest African Americans from moving into  a white neighborhood in Longview Texas

summary: 6/29/1970: Suspected members of the Black Panther Party bombed the Harvey Ingham Hall of Science at Drake University in Des Moines, Iowa, United States.  There were no casualties but the explosion caused an estimated $300,000 in damage to the building.
target1: Harvey Ingham Hall of Science at Drake University
weapdetail: 15 to 20 pounds of high power dynamite
propcomment: Building sustained heavy damages
addnotes: On May 5th 1970, a large quantity of dynamite was stolen from Quick Supply, a dynamite supply warehouse in Ankeny Iowa.  Police believed that the stolen dynamite was used by the Black Panthers in this attack as well as in four other incidents taking place in Iowa during May and June 1970 (197005130001, 197005220003, 197006130001, and 197006210001).

summary: 6/29/1970: Suspected revolutionary leftists threw a pipe bomb filled with gunpowder at the Whitefish Bay Bank & Trust Company in Whitefish Bay, Wisconsin, United States.  The bomb did not detonate.  This incident was believed to be linked to the many bombings in the Milwaukee, Wisconsin area during this time period.
weapdetail: Thrown pipe bomb filled with gunpowder
addnotes: The bomb was labeled "We the People No. 1."  The Whitefish Bay Chief of Police believed that this incident might be linked with bombs discovered at the Whitefish Bay Police Department, Lakeside Laboratories, Honeywell Inc. and the Wisconsin Motor Division (197010280002, 197009040004, 197007000001, and 197008050001).   There were other bombings in the Milwaukee area during this time period as well (197012220001, 197007220002, and 197007210004).

scite3: "Bomb Rips Offices of Company Here," Milwaukee Journal, August 5, 1970.

summary: 6/30/1970: Two policemen, Robert M. Perry and Robert G. Beck, were shot by snipers in Plainfield, New Jersey, United States after responding to a fire at a vacant shop.  Officer Perry would eventually die from his injuries.  City officials believed that radical African Americans intentionally set the fire to lure the policemen into the area.  Firefighters fighting the blaze were also shot at.
corp1: Police and firefighters of Plainfield New Jersey
target1: Police and firefighters at the scene of a fire in the African American part of town in Plainfield New Jersey
motive: To spark community wide turmoil
addnotes: This attack took place during heightened racial tensions in Plainfield New Jersey.  Over a year later, Police Officer Frank Buczek was killed two blocks away (197109180002).
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

Only about half of the devices ignited successfully.  Police believe that this incident was linked to the firebombing of a Woolworth's store a month earlier (197006060004).

summary: 7/0/1970: An unexploded bomb was discovered at Honeywell Incorporated in Wauwatosa, Wisconsin, United States.  This incident was believed to be linked to the many bombings perpetrated by revolutionary leftists in the Milwaukee, Wisconsin area during this time period.
addnotes: The Whitefish Bay Chief of Police believed that this incident might be linked with bombs discovered at the Whitefish Bay State Bank, Whitefish Bay Police Department, Lakeside Laboratories, and the Wisconsin Motor Division (197010280002, 197009040004, 197006290002, and 197008050001).   There were other bombings in the Milwaukee area during this time period as well (197012220001, 197007220002, and 197007210004).

summary: 7/0/1970: Unknown perpetrators set a fire at St. Ann's Church in Boston, Massachusetts, United States.  There were no casualties but the blaze caused $5,000 in damages.  This is believed to be part of a campaign to scare Whites out of the Dorchester area.
corp1: Catholic Church in the Dorchester area of Boston
motive: To scare White Catholic residents of the Dorchester out of the area
propcomment: Church damaged
addnotes: Arsonists set a fire at St. Ann's Church around two months earlier (197005000001).  Two synagogues in Dorchester sustained three arson attacks during this same time period (197005060007, 197005270002, and 197005270003).
scite1: Gerald H. Gamm, "Urban Exodus: Why the Jews Left Boston and the Catholics Stayed," Harvard University Press, 1999.

summary: 7/1/1970: Members of the Revolutionary Force Seven threw a pipe bomb through the back door of the Inter-American Defense Board building in Washington D.C., United States.  There were no casualties but the chauffeur room and a bathroom were damaged.
target1: Inter-American Defense Board building, Washington D.C.
motive: To protest the policies of the Organization of American States
weapdetail: Pipe bomb thrown into the building
propcomment: Damage to chauffeur's room and an adjoining bathroom
addnotes: This attack was linked to firebombings against four Latin American embassies in Washington D.C. by the Revolution Force 7 one day later (197007020001, 197007020002, 197007020003, and 197007020004).  The Revolutionary Force 7 claimed the attack by delivering a letter to The Associated Press.  The Inter-American Defense Board is an agency of the Organization of American States.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Alexander Ward, "Fire Bombs Damage 4 Embassies," Washington Post, July 3, 1970.
scite3: "Group Takes Credit For Bomb Damage," Sarasota Herald Tribune, July 2, 1970.

summary: 7/1/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed a classroom in the University of California's Center for East Asian Studies in Berkeley, California, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained $7,000 in damages.
target1: Center for East Asian Studies, University of California, Berkeley
weapdetail: Powder filled pipe bomb attached to a timing device
propcomment: A few rooms in the building were damaged
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Robert W. Peterson, "Crime & the American Response," Facts on File, 1973.
scite3: "Bomb Damages College Building," Gettysburg Times, July 1, 1970.

summary: 7/2/1970: Suspected Black Panthers bombed the Components Concept Corporation, a Black-owned business in Omaha, Nebraska, United States.  There were no casualties but the building was destroyed and equipment within the building was damaged.
corp1: Black owned business working on a government contract
motive: To protest Blacks supporting the establishment.
propcomment: Building damaged and equipment within facility was damaged
addnotes: It is believed that the materials of the bomb in this incident were similar to the materials used in the bombing of the Omaha Police Station a month earlier (197006110003).  The owner of the business had publicly thanked the city council and a local bank for their assistance in moving his company to a larger building.  It is believed that the owner was considered an "Uncle Tom."
scite1: Committee on Internal Security House of Representatives, "Black Panther Party, Part 4," U.S. Government Printing Office, October-November, 1970.
scite2: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

location: One hundred feet from police station
summary: 7/2/1970: Tommy L. Harper, an African American, was killed when a bomb that he was carrying prematurely exploded when he was one hundred feet away from the Compton Police Station in California, United States.  It is suspected that he was attempting to bomb the police station.  Windows were shattered at a building and automobile that were in the vicinity of the explosion.
weapdetail: A makeshift bomb connected to a clock device
propcomment: Windows of an automobile in the area and the windows of an adjacent building were shattered
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Carrier of Bomb Blown To Pieces in California," Washington Post, July 3, 1970.

summary: 7/3/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed a bomb outside of the apartment of New York State Supreme Court Justice Jawn A. Sandifer in Manhattan, New York, United States.  The bomb was discovered inside a shopping bag at the door of the apartment by a maintenance employee and subsequently dismantled by the bomb squad.  Justice Sandifer and his family were vacationing in New Jersey at the time of the incident.
target1: Apartment of Justice Jawn A. Sandifer
weapdetail: One by twelve inch pipe bomb, a bottle of gasoline and a timing device in a cardboard box
addnotes: Police were unsure of the motives behind the attack.  Justice Sandifer, an African American, was a former civil rights lawyer but had not been involved in any civil rights cases around the time of the incident.  Police stated that the bomb was built by an amateur but would have caused extensive damage if it ignited.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Bomb Discovered Outside Apartment Of a Judge Here," New York Times, July 4, 1970.
scite3: "Bomb Is Found At Judge's Door," Washington Post, July 4, 1970.

summary: 7/3/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed the University Federal Savings and Loan Building in Seattle, Washington, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained $3,000 in damages.
target1: University Federal Savings and Loan Building, Seattle Washington
addnotes: Police suspected that the attack was carried out in retaliation for the shooting of Larry Ward (197005150004).  However, the Seattle Liberation Front also claimed the attack in a letter sent to the Berkeley Bear, an underground left-wing newspaper in Berkeley California.

summary: 7/4/1970: Gerard Malloy tossed a Molotov cocktail at an Army truck stationed at Fort Hamilton in New York, United States.  There were no casualties but the vehicle was badly damaged.

motive: To protest the Vietnam War
propcomment: Army truck heavily damaged
addnotes: The vehicle was a 1967 Ford panel truck.

location: Underneath buses on the outside rows
summary: 7/4/1970: Fred Loyd Hayes and Kenneth Ray McMaster placed twenty seven nitroglycerine explosives underneath buses stationed at the Longview school district maintenance yard in Longview, Texas, United States.  Attached to a common detonator, the bombs exploded simultaneously, damaging a total of thirty three buses at a cost of around $100,000.  There were no casualties.  Hayes and McMaster carried out the bombing to prevent the busing of African Americans to recently desegregated schools.
target1: School buses of the Longview Texas School District
motive: To prevent the busing of African American students to the desegregated school in the Longview School District
weapdetail: Twenty seven nitroglycerine charges attached to a common detonator
propcomment: Thirty three buses damaged.  Almost half of those buses sustained heavy damages.  Every bus but one, was eventually put back into service.
addnotes: McMaster and Hayes entered the maintenance yard by cutting through a fence.  They were both found guilty and received eleven year prison sentences.  Hayes also carried out an attack on an African American owned house in Longview Texas two weeks earlier (197006250001).
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "School Buses Are Bombed," Baltimore Sun, July 6, 1970.
scite3: "2 Are Indicted in Bombing Of 36 School Buses," New York Times, July 26, 1970.

summary: 7/4/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a pipe bomb through the garage window of Ben Maidenburg's house in Akron, Ohio, United States.  Maidenburg was the publisher of the Akron Beacon Journal.  There were no casualties but the blast caused $10,000 in damages.
target2: Home of the publisher of the Akron Beacon Journal
motive: To protest the reporting of the Akron Beacon Journal
weapdetail: Pipe filled with explosives thrown into garage
propcomment: Car damaged and metal fragments ripped into the house
addnotes: Seven months later there was an attempted bombing at Ben Maidenburg's house by a Neo-Nazi (197102100003).
scite1: "Neo-Nazi Accused of Placing Bomb at Publisher's Home," New York Times, March 18, 1971.
scite2: "Bomb Left At Home of Publisher," Washington Post, February 12, 1971.
scite3: "Arrest Follows Kidnap Threat To Publisher," Sarasota Herald-Tribune, March 6, 1974.

summary: 7/4/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed the Long Beach Democratic Committee headquarters in Long Beach, New York, United States.  There were no casualties and it is unknown if the headquarters sustained any damages.
target1: Long Beach Democratic Committee headquarters, New York
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 7/4/1970: Two youths were hired by Frank Thurber, a member of a union affiliated with the striking Typographical Union, shot and killed Allan W. Daly at his home in San Francisco, California, United States.  Daly was a non-striking member of the San Rafael Independent Journal.
corp1: Non striking member of the San Rafael Independent Journal
motive: To protest non-participants in the San Rafael Independent Journal strike
addnotes: Allan Daly survived two weeks before finally succumbing to his wounds.  Frank Thurber belonged to the San Francisco Mailers Union.  Thurber offered Richard Wamsley and Larry Rutherford $300 to "rough up" Daly.  Thurber provided them with a weapon and drove the to Daly's home.  Printers used by non-striking members of the San Rafael Independent journal were firebombed days later (197007080002).
scite1: "Nonstriker At Paper Succumbs To Wounds," Los Angeles Times, July 17, 1970.
scite2: "Home of Nonstriking Printers Fire-Bombed; 6 Escape Injury," Los Angeles Times, July 9, 1970.
scite3: "Slayer Given Life Sentence," The Bulletin, December 10, 1970.

summary: 7/5/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed a total of eleven firebombs underneath five police radio cars in the parking lot of a police station in Queens, New York United States.  The firebombs, which failed to explode due to faulty fuses, were discovered by a patrolman on security duty and were removed.
target1: Police Cars parked at a police station in Queens
weapdetail: Eleven bottles of wine filled with an unspecified liquid and firecrackers attached to cigarette tied fuses
addnotes: The cigarettes tied to the fuses went out before they had a chance to ignite the firebombs.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 7/8/1970: Gaylen Alexander and Billy Joel Oglesby detonated an explosive device in a dynamite warehouse owned by the Atlas Powder Company in Oneonta, Alabama, United States.  The blast ignited two-thousand cases of dynamite stored at the warehouse destroying the building.  There were no casualties but windows were shattered at buildings within an eight mile radius of the warehouse.

weapdetail: Explosive device connected to a wire strung to the warehouse from a car battery about five hundred feet away
propcomment: Warehouse destroyed and twenty-five large plate-glass windows shattered
addnotes: Authorities were unsure of the motive behind the attack.  National Guardsmen were called up to Oneonta to prevent the stores that were damaged by the blast from being looted.

scite2: "Dynamite Warehouse Sabotaged," Washington Post, July 10, 1970.
scite3: "2 Charged With Sabotage In Dynamite Plant Blast," Tri-City Herald, July 8, 1970.

summary: 7/8/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a Molotov Cocktail into a home that housed two printers for the strike-bound San Rafael Independent Journal in Petaluma, California, United States.  Six people escaped from the house without injury but the interior of the house was damaged.
target1: Home housing printers for the San Rafael Independent Journal
corp2: Residence housing printers for the San Rafael Independent Journal
motive: To protest individuals not participating in the strike of the San Rafael Independent Journal
propcomment: Bathroom gutted and hallway damaged
addnotes: Four days earlier a non striking member of the San Rafael Independent Journal was shot (197007040006).
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Home of Nonstriking Printers Fire-Bombed; 6 Escape Injury," Los Angeles Times, July 9, 1970.

summary: 7/9/1970: Unknown perpetrators set a fire in the Selective Service office in Des Plaines, Illinois, United States.  The fire, however, extinguished itself and only a desk and table were destroyed.
target1: Selective Service office, Des Plaines Illinois
motive: To protest and sabotage the draft
weapdetail: Three holes drilled in ceiling of the office.  Flammable liquid poured through the holes followed by paper towels lit on fire.
propcomment: Desk and table destroyed
addnotes: Two of the three holes drilled into the building were over cross beams, and the flammable liquid caused no damage.
scite1: Barry Polsky, "News Briefs," Chicago Tribune, July 10, 1970.
scite2: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 7/11/1970: Unknown White perpetrators fired shotgun blasts indiscriminately into a crowd of African American youths in New Bedford, Massachusetts, United States.  Lester Lima was killed and Kim Holland, Randall Robinson, and Gordon Ribiro were wounded.  This attack sparked widespread rioting by the African American community of New Bedford.
target1: African Americans in New Bedford Massachusetts
motive: Intimidate the African American community of New Bedford Massachusetts.
weapdetail: Shotgun blasts were fired in rapid succession.
addnotes: This attack greatly increased the racial strife of the already violent conflict between the White and Black communities of New Bedford.  The mayor of New Bedford instituted a curfew in response to the riots that spread of control as a result to this attack.  Three Whites, Ralph Brown, Gary DesLauriers, and George Rose, were arrested and charged for the crime but were eventually acquitted.
scite1: Bill Kovach, "New Bedford Gets Curfew To Ease Racial Tensions," New York Times, July 13, 1970.
scite2: "New Bedford Negro Killed; 3 Are Held," New York Times, July 12, 1970.
scite3: "3 Youths Acquitted in Death of Negro in New Bedford," New York Times, May 19, 1971.

summary: 7/14/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw two Molotov cocktails and bricks into the Tri-City Human Relations Council building in Chicago, Illinois, United States.  There were no casualties and the building sustained only minor damages.  The council was involved in an anti-discrimination lawsuit against various housing developers and real estate brokers in Chicago.
motive: Protesting the multiple housing discrimination lawsuits that the Tri-Cities Human Relations Council was involved with.
weapdetail: Two Molotov cocktails and bricks were thrown at the office.
propcomment: The fire caused minor damage and three windows were broken.
scite1: Leroy Thomas, "S. Side Agency Firebombed," Chicago Daily Defender, July 15, 1970.
scite2: "Firebomb Attack On Southside, Agency Hit Condemns Firebomb Attack," Chicago Daily Defender, July 16, 1970.
scite3: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 7/14/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed a Marine Corp Recruiting Booth in New York City, United States. There were no casualties and it is unknown if the recruiting booth sustained any damages.
target1: Marine Recruiting Booth, New York City
motive: Protest the draft and the US military
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 7/16/1970: The offices of the Southeast Community Organization of Chicago, Illinois, United States were firebombed by unknown perpetrators.  There were no casualties and it is unknown if the building sustained any damages.  This incident took place two days after the Tri-City Human Relations Council building in Chicago was firebombed.
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 7/16/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed a Marine Corps Recruiting Office in Brooklyn, New York, United States.  There were no casualties and it is unknown if the recruiting office sustained any damages.
target1: Marine Recruiting Office, Brooklyn New York
motive: Protest the draft and the US military
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 7/16/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed the Dakota County Selective Service Office in St. Paul, Minnesota, United States.  There were no casualties and it is unknown if the Selective Service office sustained any damages.
target1: Dakota County Selective Service Office, St. Paul Minnesota
motive: To protest and sabotage the draft
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 7/17/1970: Chicago police officers Tony Rizzato and James Severin were killed by snipers while patrolling an open area at the Mother Cabrini Homes project in Chicago, Illinois, United States.  Two African Americans, Johnnie Veal and George Knights, were convicted of the murders.
target1: Chicago Police Officers patrolling the Mother Cabrini Homes project
motive: To kill police
propcomment: Windows shattered at surrounding buildings
addnotes: This was one of many sniping attacks against police in the Mother Cabrini Homes project.  The shots were fired from the sixth floor of an apartment building.  The perpetrators shot at the police as they attempted to tend to officers Severin and Rizzato.
scite1: "Chicago Sniping Kills 2 Policemen," New York Times, July 18, 1970.
scite2: "3 Youths Charged in Sniper Killings," Washington Post, July 19, 1970.
scite3: "2 Convicted of Chicago Sniping," Milwaukee Journal, August 26, 1971.

summary: 7/18/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed the Broadway Savings Bank in Manhattan, New York, United States.  There were no casualties but windows and glass doors were shattered.
target1: Broadway Savings Bank, Park Place branch
weapdetail: Times pipe bomb with batteries and a clock
propcomment: Glass door and windows shattered
addnotes: This was one of many bank bombings in New York City during 1970.
scite1: "Pipe Bomb Shatters Glass At a Bank on Park Place," New York Times, July 19, 1970.
scite2: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 7/20/1970: Suspected Black nationalists firebombed the Crown Heights Jewish Community Council in Brooklyn, New York, United States.  There were no casualties, however, the building was heavily damaged.
motive: To protest the Jewish agency's operations in a predominantly Black community.
weapdetail: Firebombs were thrown at the building
propcomment: The interior of the building was destroyed.
addnotes: A witness reported that three youths threw an object at the building.  The attack took place during rising tensions between the Black and Jewish communities in Crown Heights.  New York City Mayor, John Lindsay, established the Crown Heights Urban Actions Task Force two days after the attack.  The task force was set up to deal with community problems.
scite1: Deirdre Carmody, "Firebombing Heavily Damages Crown Heights Jewish Center," New York Times, July 21,1970.
scite2: "Crown Hgts. Opens Task Force Office," New York Amsterdam News, August 1, 1970.

summary: 7/21/1970: Two cars being prepared for delivery to the New York Police Department were bombed in Queens, New York, United States.  There were no casualties, but both cars sustained damages.  A crudely made Vietcong flag was discovered at the scene.
target1: Station Wagons being converted into police vehicles at the Airport Motors storage lot
motive: Protest the War in Vietnam
propcomment: Both cars were damaged
scite1: "Two Police Vehicles Damaged By Bombs," New York Times, July 22, 1970.

summary: 7/21/1970: Suspected revolutionary leftists  bombed a truck at the South Side Reserve Headquarters in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, United States.  There were no casualties but the blast caused minor damage.  There were many other bombings in the Milwaukee area during this time period.
target1: South Side Reserve Headquarters, Milwaukee Wisconsin
propcomment: Minor damage
addnotes: This was one of many bombings and attempted bombings that took place in the Milwaukee Wisconsin area during a five month period. (197012220001, 197010280002, 197007220002, 197009040004, 197006290002, 197007000001, and 197008050001).
scite1: "Bomb Rips Offices of Company Here," Milwaukee Journal, August 5, 1970.

summary: 7/22/1970: Suspected revolutionary leftists bombed a fuel line at the Wisconsin Petroleum Terminal Corporation in Jones Island, Wisconsin, United States.  There were no casualties but twelve thousand gallons of fuel oil leaked out of the pipe and around eighteen windows on the premises were shattered.  There were many other bombings in the Milwaukee, Wisconsin area during this time period.
target1: Fuel line at the Wisconsin Petroleum Terminal Corporation in Jones Island
propcomment: Twelve thousand gallons of fuel oil leaked from the tank and eighteen windows of offices at the firm were shattered
addnotes: The bomb was placed next to the fuel pipe.  This was one of many bombings and attempted bombings that took place in the Milwaukee Wisconsin area during a five month period. (197012220001, 197010280002, 197009040004, 197006290002, 197007000001, 197008050001, and 197007210004).
scite1: "Jones Island Oil Firm Rocked by Explosion," Milwaukee Journal, July 23, 1970.
scite2: "Pipe Hints at Oil Firm Bomb," Milwaukee Journal, July 24, 1970.
scite3: Alex P. Dobish, "Bay Offers $2,500 Reward for Squad Car Bomber," Milwaukee Journal, November 3, 1970.

summary: 7/22/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed an Army Recruiting Trailer in Camden, New Jersey, United States.  There were no casualties and it is unknown if the trailer was damaged.
target1: Army Recruiting Trailer, Camden New Jersey
motive: Protest the draft and the US military
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 7/23/1970: Unknown perpetrators, located on the Grove-Shafter Freeway, threw a bomb at the California Highway Patrol office in Oakland, California, United States.  The bomb landed fifty feet away from the building and created a small hole in the ground.
target1: California Highway Patrol office, Oakland California
weapdetail: Thrown bomb that consisted of black power and filled with nuts and bolts.
propcomment: Small hole in gravel lot
addnotes: There were three other bombings on government targets in the Oakland area within a seven day period (197007270004, 197007270005, 197007300001).  Moreover, a bomb was thrown at the California High Patrol office in Santé Fe Springs five weeks later (197008290004).
scite1: "The State: Bomb Explodes Near Oakland CHP Office," Los Angeles Times, July 24, 1970.
scite2: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 7/24/1970: Members of the Jewish Defense League failed in their attempts to firebomb a Black Community Center in Brooklyn, New York, United States.  This incident occurred four days after the Crown Heights Jewish Community Council in Brooklyn was firebombed by suspected African American militants.
target1: Black Community Center in Crown Heights New York
motive: Revenge for the firebombing of a Jewish Community Center in Brooklyn
addnotes: Four days earlier, a Jewish Community Center in New York City was firebombed by suspected Black militants (197007200001).  A weeks later, there would be another attempted attack on the Black Community Center by the JDL (197008180001).
scite1: Robert I. Friedman, "The False Prophet: Rabbi Meir Kahane," Lawrence Hill Books, 1990.
scite2: Shlomo Russ, "Zionist Hooligans: The Jewish Defense League," City University of New York, 1981.

target1: Bank of America, wall st. office

summary: 7/27/1970: In a series of related attack, unknown perpetrators bombed the Armed Forces Police Station in San Francisco, California, United States.  There were no casualties but the bomb created a five inch hole in the office of the commanding officer and shattered windows at the army base.
target1: Armed Forces Police Headquarters, San Francisco
propcomment: Five inch hole in the office of the commanding officer and windows shattered
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197007270005.  Four days earlier, a  bomb was thrown at the California High Patrol office in Oakland and three days after the incident, the Oakland Hall of Justice was bombed (197007230002 and 197007300001).
scite1: "N.Y. Bank Damaged by Pipe Bomb," New York Times, July 28, 1970.
scite2: "Army Target at Coast Blasts," New York Times, July 28, 1970.
scite3: "Bomb Breaks Glass In Police Building," Modesto Bee, July 31, 1970.

summary: 7/27/1970: In a series of related attack, unknown perpetrators bombed a historic Nike missile located at the Army Presidio in San Francisco, California, United States.  There were no casualties but the bomb caused minor damages.
propcomment: Missile damaged
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197007270004.  Four days earlier, a bomb was thrown at the California High Patrol office in Oakland and three days after the incident, the Oakland Hall of Justice was bombed (197007230002 and 197007300001).  There are conflicting reports as to whether the missile itself was damaged.
scite1: "Army Target at Coast Blasts," New York Times, July 28, 1970.
scite2: "Bomb Breaks Glass In Police Building," Modesto Bee, July 31, 1970.
scite3: "Guerrilla Acts of Sabotage and Terrorism in the United States 1965-1970," Scanlan's Magazine, January 1971.

summary: 7/31/1970: Unknown perpetrators fired shotgun blasts at the house of the first African American family to move into a White neighborhood in Charlotte,North Carolina, United States.  There were no casualties but it is uknown if the house was damaged.
target1: Home of Mr. & Mrs. Franklin Williams
motive: To scare the African American family into leaving neighborhood and to intimidate future African American families from moving into the neighborhood.
propcomment: It is unknown if any of the bullets hit the house.
addnotes: The family earlier received a threatening note telling them to leave the neighborhood or they would be in danger.  Though the Williams were frightened, White neighbors consoled them and convinced them to stay in the neighborhood.
scite1: "N.C. Negroes Stay," Washington Post, September 6, 1970.

summary: 8/2/1970: Unknown perpetrators taped a bomb to a police car driven by Officer Robert F. Maloney in Berkeley, California, United States.  The bomb exploded, rupturing the gasoline tank, and sending flames twenty five feet up into the air.  Officer Maloney was able to escape the vehicle unharmed but the car was destroyed.
propcomment: Back half of the vehicle consumed by flames
addnotes: Before the bomb exploded Officer Maloney left his vehicle for ten minutes to investigate a domestic complaint.
scite1: "Policeman Escapes Berkeley Bombing," Washington Post, August 4, 1970.
scite2: "Police Car Explodes," Reading Eagle, August 3, 1970.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 8/5/1970: Suspected revolutionary leftists bombed a research laboratory of the Wisconsin Motors Division of Continental Motors Corporation in Milwaukee, United States.  There were no casualties but the bomb caused $10,000 in damages to the laboratory.  There were many other bombings in the Milwaukee area during this time period.
target1: Wisconsin Motors Division of Continental Motors Corporation, Milwaukee Wisconsin
weapdetail: Seven inch pipe bomb consisting of gunpowder and a wick fuse
propcomment: Two offices damaged.  Hole ripped through ceiling and windows shattered.
addnotes: The perpetrator forced open a door in the building and placed the bomb on a row of file cabinets in the laboratory.  The bomb detonated at 3:44 AM.  The research facilities received bomb threats two and a half months before the attack, but they were dismissed.  Military research was not conducted at the laboratory.  The Whitefish Bay Chief of Police believed that this incident might be linked with bombs discovered at the Whitefish Bay State Bank, Whitefish Bay Police Department, Lakeside Laboratories, and the Honeywell Inc. (197010280002, 197009040004, 197006290002, and 197007000001).   There were other bombings in the Milwaukee area during this time period as well (197012220001, 197007220002, and 197007210004).
scite1: "Bomb Rips Offices of Company Here," Milwaukee Journal, August 5, 1970.
scite2: "Door Forced Open In Plant Bombing," Milwaukee Sentinel, August 6, 1970.
scite3: Alex P. Dobish, "Bay Offers $2,500 Reward for Squad Car Bomber," Milwaukee Journal, November 3, 1970.

location: Intersection of Santa Clara Street and 11th Street
summary: 8/6/1970: Police Officer Richard Huerta was shot dead by Emile Thompson, a Black nationalist, while he was sitting in his car writing out a traffic ticket in San Jose, California, United Station.
motive: To kill police
propcomment: Four shots hit officer Huerta
addnotes: Emile Thompson claimed that he carried out the attack to get back at the 'pigs' who had harassed him, noting that Officer Huerta represented all 'pigs.'  In 1970, there were two other police officers murdered by suspected Black Nationalists in the Northern California area while they were making traffic stops (197008200003 and 197006190004).
scite1: Betty Barnacle, "Chief Opposes Parole for Cop Killer," Mercury News, June 4, 1995.
scite2: "Young Policeman Slain In Berkeley," New York Times, August 21, 1970.
scite3: "SJPD Fallen Officers: Officer Richard E. Huerta," San Jose Police Department, 2010. <http://www.sjpd.org/InsideSJPD/Fallen/Huerta.html>

summary: 8/7/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a Molotov cocktail through the door window of a Selective Service Office in Dundalk, Maryland, United States.  There were no casualties but the damages to the building and draft records amounted to about $600.
target1: Dundalk Selective Service Office, Local Board 37
motive: Protest and sabotage the draft
propcomment: Minor damage to building and draft records
addnotes: The draft records that were damaged belonged to soldiers who were unlikely to be drafted.
scite1: "Draft Board Fire Probed," Baltimore Sun, August 9, 1970.
scite2: "Draft Office In Maryland Firebombed," Washington Post, August 9, 1970.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 8/10/1970: Four members of the White Panthers Party threw three firebombs through the windows of Oregon's Selective Service Headquarters in Portland, United States.  There were no casualties but the resulting fire caused around $1,000 of damage to furniture within two offices.
motive: Protest and sabotage the draft
weapdetail: Three Molotov cocktails consisting of wine bottles and gasoline
propcomment: Two desks, several chairs, mail, and a rug were damaged by the fire
addnotes: An alert custodian extinguished the fires before they had a chance to cause significant damages.  In a sixth month period, the Oregon Selective Service Headquarters was firebombed three other times (197002010001, 197005060006, and 197006030001).
scite1: "Draft Office Bombed 4th Time," Washington Post, August 11, 1970.
scite2: 450 F.2d 308, "United States of America v. Robert Gerrahan Yaple Jr.," United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit, October 14, 1971.
scite3: "Selective Service Office Damaged By 3 Firebombs," Eugene Register-Guard, August 10, 1970.

location: Parking lot of a West Point grocery store
summary: 8/15/1970: John Thomas was shot to death in his car in West Point, Mississippi, United States.  Thomas was a civil rights activist who previously led the campaign of a Black mayoral candidate.  The shooter, Seth Stanley, a White male, was found not guilty by means of self defense by an all-White jury.
addnotes: John Thomas was one of the accused perpetrators of 197001250001.  Seth Stanley was acquitted based on a successful argument of self defense, but it is important to note that John Thomas was shot as he was sitting in his truck.  A Black boycott of White-owned businesses in West Point was initiated as a result of this incident.
scite1: "Mississippi White Cleared in Killing," New York Times, October 12, 1971.
scite2: "Kin of NAACP Lobbyist Mitchell Wins Balto Primary Recount," New Pittsburgh Courier, October 10, 1970.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 8/17/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed twenty sticks of dynamite in an a federal office building housing the Armed Forces Examination Center in Minneapolis, Minnesota, United States.  The resulting explosion knocked a night watchman unconscious and caused an estimated $500,000 in damage to the building.  Windows were shattered at buildings within a one block radius of the explosion.
target1: Armed Forces Examination Center, Minneapolis Minnesota
motive: Protest and sabotage the draft and the US Army
propcomment: Extensive damage to the building and windows shattered at buildings within the surrounding area
addnotes: The federal office building had been the site of many anti-war demonstrations.  Following the explosion, police reported six false bomb threats in Minneapolis.  Police Officer Joseph Christy was knocked unconscious by the blast but he would recover from his injuries.
scite1: "Bombs Kill Officer, Rip U.S. Building," Washington Post, August 18, 1970.
scite2: "Minneapolis Bomb 'Very Well Placed,'" New York Times, August 19, 1970.
scite3: "Explosion Rips Federal Building At Minneapolis," The Evening Independent, August 17, 1970.

summary: 8/18/1970: Members of the Jewish Defense League failed in their attempts to firebomb a Black Community Center in Brooklyn, New York, United States.  This incident occurred a month after the Crown Heights Jewish Community Council in Brooklyn was firebombed by suspected African American militants.
target1: Black Community Center in Crown Heights New York
motive: Revenge for the firebombing of a Jewish Community Center in Brooklyn
addnotes: A month earlier, a Jewish Community Center was firebombed in New York City by suspected Black militants (197007200001). There was another attempted attack on the Black Community Center by the JDL weeks earlier (197007240002).
scite1: Robert I. Friedman, "The False Prophet: Rabbi Meir Kahane," Lawrence Hill Books, 1990.
scite2: Shlomo Russ, "Zionist Hooligans: The Jewish Defense League," City University of New York, 1981.

location: Intersection of Main Street and Chatsworth
summary: 8/20/1970: Stuart W. Baker Jr. and John Jefferson Rimes firebombed a Selective Service Office located in a Masonic Temple in Reisterstown, Maryland, United States.  There were no casualties but seven thousand draft records were destroyed or damaged and $300 worth of office equipment was also destroyed.
target1: Reisterstown Selective Service Office, Board No. 34
motive: Protest and sabotage the draft
propcomment: Seven thousand draft records damaged or destroyed and office equipment damaged
addnotes: The two perpetrators scaled a twenty foot wall and broke into the building through a window.  They attempted to set a diversionary fire at the Reisterstown Shopping Center but the firebomb malfunctioned.  After the incident, a letter was written to an underground newspaper stating that there would be more attacks against draft boards to come.  There were a total of thirty-four thousand draft records at the selective service office.  Two thousand records were destroyed and seven thousand were damaged.  All of these records were backed up on microfilm.  Moreover, none of the 1-A draft records were destroyed or damaged.
scite1: Barry Rascovar, "Police Call Fire At Draft Board Arson," Baltimore Sun, August 21, 1970.
scite2: Theodore W. Hendricks, "2 Accused In Draft Board Fires," Baltimore Sun, August 27, 1970.

location: Intersection of Union Street and Jefferson Street
summary: 8/20/1970: Police Officer Ronald T. Tsukamoto was shot and killed by an unknown perpetrator in Berkeley, California, United States.  While writing a ticket for a motorcyclist, a man walked up to Officer Tsukamoto and shot him  twice with a revolver.  The perpetrator immediately jumped in a car driven by an African American male and sped away.
motive: To kill police
addnotes: In 2005, police arrested Styles Frederick Price and Don Juan Warren Graphenreed, believing that Price carried out the murder and Graphenreed drove the getaway car.  However, the District Attorney of Alameda County declined to charge the suspects.  In 1970, there were two other police officers murdered by suspected Black Nationalists in the Northern California area while they were making traffic stops (197008060004 and 197006190004).
scite1: "Young Policeman Slain In Berkeley," New York Times, August 21, 1970.
scite2: Dorothy Vriend, "D.A. Declines To Charge Suspects In '70 Slaying," Contra Costa Times, August 19, 1970.
scite3: "Officer Slain Writing Ticket," St. Petersburg, August 21, 1970.

summary: 8/21/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed a timed firebomb in the hallway of Emerald Hall at the University Oregon in Eugene, United States.  After the firebomb ignited, the sprinkler system of the building immediately put out the blaze.  However, the building sustained around $2,750 in damages caused mainly by the water from the sprinkler system.
propcomment: Wooden cabinet damaged and floor tiles and light fixtures needed to be replaced
addnotes: The incendiary device was placed in Emerald Hall during the afternoon concealed in a cardboard box.
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite2: "Sprinkler System Thwarts Firebombing At University," Eugene Register-Guard, August 22, 1970.
scite3: "Firebomb Damage Estimate Raised," Eugene Register-Guard, August 22, 1970.

summary: 8/22/1970: Gary Hogan, a suspected member of the Black Panthers Party, placed two time bombs in Dayton's Department Store in St. Paul, Minnesota, United States.  The first bomb detonated severely injuring one woman and causing damages to the restroom.  The second bomb, ten times more powerful that the first, was discovered and disarmed outside of the restroom by police.  It is believed that the second bomb was intended to kill police officers responding to the scene of the first bomb.
target1: St. Paul Police Officers responding to a bombing
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: One time bomb consisting of two sticks of dynamite and another time bomb consisting of twenty sticks of dynamite
propcomment: Restroom damaged
addnotes: Mary Peek was seriously injured but would survive her wounds.  Following the bombing, there were many bomb threats in St. Paul and Minneapolis.  Gary Hogan would also be convicted for planting a diversionary bomb as part of an attempted robbery of the First Grand Avenue Bank in St. Paul ten days later.
scite1: Nick Coleman, "Knowing My Place: The Victim of 8/22," St. Paul Pioneer Press, September 1, 2002.
scite2: "Woman Injured By Bomb Blast In Minnesota," Baltimore Sun, August 24, 1970.
scite3: "Bomb Blast Injured Minneapolis Shopper," Schenectady Gazette, August 24, 1970.

summary: 8/22/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed a National Guard truck stationed at an armory in Baltimore, Maryland, United States.  There were no casualties and it is unknown if there were any damages.
target1: National Guard truck stationed at army in Baltimore Maryland
motive: Protest the national guard and the US military
addnotes: The Sheridan Armory in Baltimore was bombed nine months later (197105110005).  A day before the incident, the F.B.I. released a report stating that the Ohio National Guardsmen were not fired upon during the Kent State shootings on May 4, 1970.
scite1: "3 U.S. Jeeps Set A Fire At Armory," Baltimore Sun, May 12, 1971.
scite2: "Bomb And Arson Business," Pittsburgh Press, August 26, 1970.
scite3: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

propcomment: Damages: explosion, damaged facility, estimated at $1.5 million (Army Mathmatical Research Center)

summary: 8/25/1970: Unknown revolutionary leftists tossed a Molotov cocktail into the Police Headquarters in Burlington, Massachusetts, United States.  The only Police Officer on duty, Ronald I. Glejzer, escaped without injury however the building was destroyed.
motive: Offensive against police
weapdetail: Molotov cocktail thrown through a window
propcomment: The building was destroyed and most police records were lost.  Police communication systems were also heavily damaged.
addnotes: When the Proud Eagle Tribe, an offshoot of the Weather Underground, claimed credit for the bombing of Harvard University's Center for International Affairs on October 14th (197010140001), they stated that firebombing of the Burlington Police Station was the result of "kids wag(ing) an offensive against the town pigs."
scite1: "A Police Station Damaged By Bomb," New York Times, August 27, 1970.
scite2: "Women Radicals Take The Credit In Harvard Blast," Baltimore Sun, October 15, 1970.
