summary: 8/27/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed an incendiary device connected to a detonator on the window ledge of a kitchen within the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts, United States.  The device was discovered and subsequently disarmed.
target1: Building of the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University
weapdetail: Four plastic bags contained gasoline attached to a battery and a timing device
addnotes: The incendiary device was concealed in a cardboard carton.  However, it was discovered due to the strong odor from the gasoline.
scite1: "Black Militant Held in Fatal Bombing," Washington Post, August 28, 1970.
scite2: "Incendiary Device Found At Harvard," Lewistown Evening Journal, August 28, 1970.
scite3: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

location: Outside of the G.W. Bullick School
summary: 8/28/1970: Two explosive charges were set off at the G. W. Bullick School in Rocky Mount, North Carolina, United States.  The school was scheduled to be integrated.  There were no casualties in the attack and the school sustained minor damage.
motive: To prevent the school from desegregating.
weapdetail: The explosives were suspected of being dynamite.  They went off moments apart.
propcomment: A wall was damaged and a water tank were damaged.  15 windows were shattered.
scite1: "2 Blasts Damage Carolina School," New York Times, August 29, 1970.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 8/28/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed the National Guard Armory in Walnut Creek, California, United States.  There were no casualties and it is unknown if the armory was damaged.
target1: National Guard Armory, Walnut Creek California
motive: To protest and sabotage the National Guard
addnotes: The next day, a municipal court building in Walnut Creek California was firebombed (197008290003).
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 8/28/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed a municipal court building in Walnut Creek, California, United States.  There were no casualties and it is unknown if the building was damaged.
target1: Municipal court building, Walnut Creek California
addnotes: A day before the incident, the National Guard Armory in Walnut Creek California was firebombed (197008280002).
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 8/29/1970:  Unknown perpetrators placed a bomb in front of the California Highway Patrol office in Santa Fe Springs, California, United States.  The bomb was discovered and subsequently disarmed.
target1: California Highway Patrol office, Oakland California
weapdetail: Seven sticks of dynamite and a blasting cap
addnotes: A bomb was thrown at the California High Patrol office in Oakland five weeks earlier (197007230002).
scite1: "Metropolitan: Lost Radioactive Material Hunted," Los Angeles Times, August 30, 1970.

summary: 8/30/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a Molotov cocktail through the window of the R.O.T.C. building at the University of Georgia in Athens, United States.  The resulting fire was put out almost immediately by the sprinkler system, however, one classroom sustained minor water damage.
motive: To protest the R.O.T.C. program and the war in Vietnam
weapdetail: Molotov cocktail consisting of a soft drink bottle filled with a flammable liquid
propcomment: Water damage in classroom from sprinkler system
scite1: "Georgia News Briefs," Rome News-Tribune, August 31, 1970.
scite2: "Blaze Reported At R.O.T.C. Building," Herald-Journal, August 31, 1970.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 9/2/1970: Unknown perpetrators, stationed in a car, threw a bomb into an unoccupied police vehicle that was located in a predominantly African American neighborhood in San Francisco, California, United States.  There were no casualties but the car was extensively damaged.
motive: Offensive against police
weapdetail: Bomb thrown into police car from a passing vehicle
propcomment: Extensive damage
addnotes: The vehicle was unoccupied because the police officers were investigating a robbery.  Authorities believed that the robbery complaint was legitimate.
scite1: "Empty Patrol Car Damaged By Bomb," Washington Post, September 4, 1970.
scite2: "2 Coast Car Plants Damaged By Bombs," New York Times, September 4, 1970.
scite3: "Bombed Police Car," The Bulletin, September 3, 1970.

summary: 9/2/1970: In a series of two incidents that were possibly part of a multiple attack, unknown perpetrators detonated a bomb at the Ford Motor Company's plant in Milpitas, California, United States.  There were no casualties but windows in the front lobby were shattered.
target1: Ford Motor Company plant in Milpitas California
propcomment: Windows shattered in front lobby
scite1: "Bombs Hit California Auto Plants," Washington Post, September 4, 1970.
scite2: "2 Coast Car Plants Damaged By Bombs," New York Times, September 4, 1970.
scite3: "Bombs Explode," The Bulletin, September 3, 1970.

summary: 9/3/1970: In a series of two incidents that were possibly part of a multiple attack, unknown perpetrator detonated a bomb at the General Motors Company's plant in Fremont, California, United States.  There were no casualties but a total of twenty-seven windows were shattered.
target1: General Motors Company plant in Fremont California
propcomment: Twenty-seven windows shattered in front lobby
scite1: "Bombs Hit California Auto Plants," Washington Post, September 4, 1970.
scite2: "2 Coast Car Plants Damaged By Bombs," New York Times, September 4, 1970.
scite3: "Bombs Explode," The Bulletin, September 3, 1970.

summary: 9/3/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed three large homemade bombs near the statue of Edward Hull Crump at Overton Park in Memphis, Tennessee, United States.  The bombs were discovered and subsequently removed by the police.
target1: E. H. Crump statue in Memphis Tennessee
addnotes: Police believe that the bombs might have not detonated even if the devices were not discovered because the bombs were exposed to rain.  E. H. Crump was a powerful political figure in Memphis Tennessee.
scite1: "Three Bombs Are Found In a Memphis Park," Washington Post, September 4, 1970.
scite2: "2 Coast Car Plants Damaged By Bombs," New York Times, September 4, 1970.

target1: Union Oil Co. Tank Storage Field

summary: 9/4/1970: Suspected revolutionary leftists attempted to bomb the Lakeside Laboratories in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, United States.  The main charge of the bomb failed to detonate.  This incident was believed to be linked to the many bombings in the Milwaukee area during this time period.
weapdetail: Pipe bomb connected to a timing device
addnotes: Authorities linked the bomb used in this incident with the bombing of a police station in Whitefish Bay on October 28th (197010280002).  Both bombs were built according to an instruction manual circulated by revolutionaries.  The Whitefish Bay Chief of Police believed that this incident might also be linked with bombs discovered at Whitefish Bay State Bank, Honeywell Inc. and the Wisconsin Motor Division (197006290002, 197007000001, and 197008050001).   There were other bombings in the Milwaukee area during this time period as well (197012220001, 197007220002, and 197007210004).
scite1: Alex P. Dobish, "Bay Offers $2,500 Reward for Squad Car Bomber," Milwaukee Journal, November 3, 1970.
scite2: "2 Bombs Tied to Rebel Manual," Milwaukee Journal, November 2, 1970.

summary: 9/4/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a bomb at the Orange County Courthouse in Santa Ana, California, United States.  The device failed to explode.
target1: Orange County Courthouse, Santa Ana California
weapdetail: Bomb consisting of a half stick of dynamite thrown at the building
addnotes: The bomb was thrown from about 35 feet away from the courthouse and landed within 5 feet of the building.  The device was discovered by a security officer at 9:35 PM.  It is believed that the bomb was thrown around an hour earlier.  The Orange County Courthouse had received many bomb threats during the year, however, there were none before this incident.  Hours after the incident, a bomb exploded in the Hall of Justice in Los Angeles (197009050002).
scite1: "Guard Discovers Unexploded Bomb Next to Courthouse," Los Angeles Times, September 9, 1970.
scite2: "Bomb Thrown at Orange Courthouse," Los Angeles Times, September 9, 1970.
scite3: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 9/5/1970: Don Clayton McMain threw a hand grenade simulator into the DeWitt Police Station in DeWitt, Iowa, United States.  Two police officers were injured and the building sustained minor damages.
propcomment: Damaged front door and scorched floor
addnotes: Police officers Harry Roeder and Ben Burken, stationed in the rear of the police station, were injured in the bombing.  Authorities were unsure of the motive behind the attack.
scite1: "Bomb Rocks Manson Trial Building," New York Times, September 6, 1970.
scite2: "2 Hurt As Explosion Rips Police Station," Baltimore Sun, September 6, 1970.
scite3: "Two Hurt In Bomb Explosion," Herald-Journal, September 6, 1970.

summary: 9/5/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed a restroom adjacent to District Attorney's Evelle J. Younger office at the Hall of Justice in Los Angeles, California, United States.  The Hall of Justice was the site where Charles Manson and three others were on trail for murdering Sharon Tate, Leno LaBianca, and Rosemary LaBianca.  There were no casualties, however the building sustained an estimate $10,000 in damages.
weapdetail: Bomb consisting of a timing device and what was believed to be dynamite
propcomment: Hole blown into the restroom wall and water main damaged which caused extensive flooding
addnotes: Three minutes after the bomb detonated, a man called the authorities warning that an explosion would occur within three minutes.  Police officials were unsure if the phone call was connected to the incident or a coincidence.  More security was placed in the Hall of Justice as a result of the bombing.  Hours before this incident, a bomb was thrown at the Orange County Courthouse in Santa Ana California (197009040005).
scite1: "Bomb Rocks Manson Trial Building," New York Times, September 6, 1970.
scite2: "Bomb Damages Tate Trial Site," Baltimore Sun, September 6, 1970.
scite3: "Bomb Damages Los Angeles Courthouse," Evening Independent, September 5, 1970.

summary: 9/6/1970: Ernest J. King failed in his attempts to bomb a garage of the Fitchburg Police Station in Fitchburg, Massachusetts, United States.  He was arrested a week later.
target1: Garage of the Fitchburg Police Station
scite1: "Bombing Arrest Made," New York Times, September 13, 1970.
scite2: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 9/9/1970: Unknown perpetrators failed in their attempts to firebomb the offices of the Kaleidoscope in Madison, Wisconsin, United States.  The Kaleidoscope was an underground newspaper that sympathized with the New Years Gang.
target1: Offices of the Kaleidoscope, Madison Wisconsin
motive: To protest the Kaleidoscope newspaper's position towards the bombing of the Army Math Research Center at the University of Wisconsin.
addnotes: The editor of the Kaleidoscope, a radical left-wing outlet, refused to reveal where the newspaper got its information from regarding articles describing the bombing of the Army Research Center at the University of Wisconsin (197008240001).
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite2: Camas ChapmanGraves, "The University in Peach and War:HC 421,"  University of Oregon, Professor Suzanne Clark, March 13, 2005.
scite3: "Blast Rocks Class Building At U Of Oregon," Modesto Bee, October 4, 1970.

summary: 9/10/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed the R.O.T.C. building at the University of Florida in Gainesville, Florida, United States.  There were no casualties but the resulting fire caused $2,000 in damages.
motive: To protest the R.O.T.C. program and the war in Vietnam
weapdetail: Firebomb consisting of a glass gallon jug
propcomment: Hallway charred and bookcases destroyed
scite1: Robert Thomas, "Fire Bomb Blamed In U of F Blaze In R.O.T.C.'s Hallway," St. Petersburg Times, September 12, 1970.
scite2: "Damaged By Flames," Daytona Beach Morning Journal, September 11, 1970.
scite3: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 9/18/1970: Police Officer William Albert Miscannon was sitting in his police car in Toledo, Ohio, United States, near the headquarters of the Black Panther Party, when an unknown perpetrator walked up to his car and shot the officer three times.  Officer Miscannon was killed and his partner Officer Walter Shaw, who was also sitting in the car, was treated for shock.
target1: Toledo Police officer stationed outside of the Black Panther Party Headquarters
motive: To kill police
addnotes: Following the attack there was a gunfight between the Toledo Police and Black Panthers.  The Police raided the headquarters of the Black Panther party an hour after the incident which directly led to the demise of the BPP within Toledo.  John McClellan was accused of carrying out the attack, but after three trials, two of which resulted in hung juries, he was acquitted.
scite1: Agis Salpukas, "A Toledo Policeman Is Shot Dead in Patrol Car," New York Times, September 19, 1970.
scite2: Joshua Boak, "After 36 Years, Slain Officer's Daughter Feels Loss," Toledo Blade, February 22, 2007.
scite3: "Bloody Chapters Added To Panther Saga," Afro-American, September 26, 1970.

summary: 10/1/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed the campaign headquarters of Parren Mitchell in Baltimore, Maryland, United States.  Mitchell was running in a contentious campaign, attempting to become the first African American Congressman from the state of Maryland.  The were no casualties and the resulting fire caused only minor damages.
corp1: Campaign Headquarters of African American Congressional Candidate
motive: To protest an African American Congressman representing the state of Maryland
weapdetail: Flammable liquid thrown through front door of building
propcomment: Minor damage
addnotes: A policeman walking by the building saw the fire and extinguished it.  Parren Mitchell received many threatening letters and phone calls during his campaign, however, he ended up victorious, becoming Maryland's first Black Congressman.
scite1: "Mitchell's Md. Headquarters Hit by Fire Bomb," Washington Post, October 2, 1970.
scite2: Paul Evans and Al Rutledge, "'Can't Stop Us,' Says Mitchell," Afro-American, October 10, 1970.
scite3: "Parren Mitchell," National Visionary Leadership Project, 2009. <http://www.visionaryproject.org/mitchellparren/>

summary: 10/2/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed Prince Lucien Campbell Hall at the University of Oregon in Eugene, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained $50,000 in damages.
target1: Prince Lucien Campbell Hall, University of Oregon
weapdetail: Twenty to twenty-five sticks of dynamite connected to a timing device
propcomment: Ceiling, walls, and heating pipes damaged
addnotes: The incident occurred overnight.  The bomb was placed in the women's restroom on the ground floor.
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 10/2/1970: Four teenagers, who were members of a Neo-Nazi group, threw four Molotov cocktails and dropped metal grates down a seventy-five foot shaft at a Sewage Pumping Station in Anne Arundel, Maryland, United States.  There were no casualties, but the station sustained $2,000 in damages.  The perpetrators attempted to provoke a racial conflict hoping that the incident would be blamed on African Americans.
target1: Sewage Plant in Anne Arundel Maryland
motive: To have the incident blamed on African American and cause racial conflict
weapdetail: Four Molotov cocktails; Metal Grates thrown down shaft
propcomment: The Molotov cocktail damaged the outside brick and the metal grates damaged the filters at the bottom of the shaft
addnotes: The four teens were members of the American Nationalist Socialist Workers, Students and Christians Party.  Only one out of the four Molotov cocktails ignited.
scite1: "Young 'Neo-Nazis' Held As Vandals," Baltimore Sun, October 20, 1970.

summary: 10/5/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed the student union at Bluefield State College in Bluefield, West Virginia, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained $15,000 in damages.
propcomment: Two restrooms were destroyed
addnotes: The bomb was placed in the men's restroom.  Two years earlier, there was a racially motivated bombing at Bluefield State College, however, authorities were unsure of the motivations behind this incident.
scite1: "Bomb Explodes at College," New York Times, October 6, 1970.
scite2: Robert W. Peterson, "Crime & the American Response," Facts on File, 1973.
scite3: "College Bombed," Beaver Country Times, October 6, 1970.

summary: 10/9/1970: A splinter group of Ku Klux Klan claimed credit for blowing up a transmitter of radio station KPFT in Houston, Texas, United States.  KPFT radio gave a platform for people with Communist views.  There were no casualties but the station was knocked of the air.
motive: Intimidating/preventing KFPT from allowing Communists a network to share their views.
propcomment: The station was temporarily knocked off the air.
addnotes: Of the four perpetrators indicted, two of them, Beam and Moratto, were Klansmen.  Hutto was also accused of being a member of the Klan.  It had been widely reported that a splinter group of the Klan took credit for the attack. The perpetrators were also indicted for 197103110001 and 197005120002.
scite1: Martin Waldron, "2 Bombings Laid to 4 in Houston," New York Times, June 12, 1971.
scite2: Martin Waldron, "Houston's KPFT, Two Bombs Later, Tries to Rebuild," New York Times, October 24, 1970.
scite3: "3 Suspected Klansmen Held in Houston, Texas," Atlanta Daily World, January 19, 1971.

summary: 10/10/1970:  The Weathermen bombed a courthouse in the Long Island City section of Queens, New York, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained $50,000 in damages.
corp1: Courthouse adjacent to the Queens House Branch House of Detention
target1: Courthouse in Long Island City Queens
weapdetail: Eight to ten sticks of dynamite
propcomment: Extensive damages to the interior of the building
addnotes: Ten minutes before the blast, the police received a phone call from the Weathermen warning of the attack.  The Weathermen claimed that the bombing was committed "in retaliation for what happened during the week."  The Queens Branch House of Detention, which was adjacent to the courthouse, also received a warning call.  There were riots at the detention center earlier in the week.  Moreover, forty-five minutes after the incident a caller warned that there was a bomb at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men.  Police searched the facility but did not find a bomb.  There were riots at that detention center earlier in the week as well.
scite1: Alfred E. Clark "F.B.I Investigates Bombing of Courthouse Here," New York Times, October 11, 1970.
scite2: "Queens Courthouse Damaged by Bomb; Warning is Given," New York Times, October 10, 1970.
scite3: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 10/15/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed a Police Storefront Center in Kansas City, Missouri, United States.  The Storefront Center was an experimental program focusing on improving relations between police and the African American community of Kansas City.  The building was damaged and Officers Kenneth Fleming and Charles Robinson were injured.
target1: Police Storefront Center, Kansas City Missouri
motive: To kill police
propcomment: Door shattered and interior of building damaged
addnotes: Police were unsure whether the bomb was thrown or placed at the building.
scite1: Warren Weaver Jr., "President Stumps For Gore's Rival," New York Times, October 21, 1970.
scite2: Jerry Sullivan, "Bombing Raises Ire Of Black Community," Free Lance-Star, October 17, 1970.
scite3: "Nixon Sees 2 Wounded Policemen," Schenectady Gazette, October 21, 1970.

summary: 10/20/1970: Black militants set fire to the Veterans of Foreign Wars Building in Cairo, Illinois, United States.  Firefighters were shot at by sniper fire coming from the nearby Pyramid Courts Housing Project and could not begin to put out the fire until the police secured the premises.  There were no casualties but the building was destroyed at a cost of an estimated $60,000.
target1: Veterans of Foreign Wars Building, Cairo Illinois
target2: Policemen and firemen responding to a fire in Cairo Illinois
motive: To kill police and firefighters
propcomment: Building was destroyed
addnotes: Police fired several hundred rounds into Pyramid Courts and it took them an hour to secure the premises.
scite1: Seth S. King, "In Cairo, Ill., Racial Tensions Remain High After Week of Shooting and Arson," New York Times, October 27, 1970.
scite2: "Bullets Hamper Battle Against Vets' Hall Fire," Modesto Bee, October 21, 1970.
scite3: "Cairo Police, Snipers Wage Battle," New York Times, October 22, 1970.

summary: 10/21/1970: Snipers positioned in and around the Pyramid Court Housing Project, armed with automatic weapons, fired on police headquarters in Cairo, Illinois, United States.  Police fired back in an exchanged that last three hours.  There were no casualties but the police station was hit by hundreds of bullets.
motive: To kill police
propcomment: Police station was hit by hundreds of bullets
addnotes: There was an attack on police headquarters less than a week later by Black militants (197010240004).  In total, thousands of rounds were fired.
scite1: Seth S. King, "In Cairo, Ill., Racial Tensions Remain High After Week of Shooting and Arson," New York Times, October 27, 1970.
scite2: "Cairo Police, Snipers Wage Battle," New York Times, October 22, 1970.

summary: 10/24/1970: Black militants ignited a fire in a White owned grocery store across the street from the Pyramid Courts Housing Project in Cairo, Illinois, United States.  Due to sniper fire, firefighters were unable to get close to the building.  There were no casualties but the store burnt down.
target1: White owned grocery store near the Pyramid Courts project in Cairo Illinois
target2: Policemen and firemen responding to a fire in Cairo Illinois
motive: To kill police and firefighters
propcomment: Grocery store destroyed
addnotes: This might be part of a multiple attack with 197010240004 which took place in Cairo an hour later.  There are conflicting reports as to whether one or two grocery stores were set on fire.  During the fire, police received a phone call stating "when are you going to send the Pigs?"
scite1: "Armed Negroes Attack Police Station in Cairo, Ill." New York Times, October 25, 1970.
scite2: "Cairo, Ill., Blacks Raid Police Station," Washington Post, October 26, 1970.
scite3: "Riflemen Attack Police Station," Deseret News, October 24, 1970.

summary: 10/24/1970: Fifteen to eighteen Black militants, dressed in military fatigues and armed with rifles, opened fire on police headquarters in Cairo, Illinois, United States, three separate times during a six hour period.  Police were able to repel each of the three attacks.  One Black militant was injured and one bystander was hit by a stray bullet.  Buildings in the surrounding area were also damaged by bullets.  In response to this attack, the mayor claimed that there was an "open armed insurrection" taking place in Cairo.
motive: To kill police
propcomment: Police station and buildings in surrounding area were damaged by bullets
addnotes: This might be part of a multiple attack with (197010240003) which took place in Cairo an hour earlier.  Snipers fired upon the police headquarters less than a week earlier (197010210003).  This first attack on the police station took place at 8:15 PM, the second attack took place at 10:15 PM, and the third attack took place at 2:10 AM on October 25th.  The final attack took thirty-five minutes and hundreds of rounds were fired.  Some of the gunmen emerged from the building that acted as the headquarters of the Black United Front, an organization which was directing a boycott of White owned businesses in Cairo at the time.  The Mayor of Cairo, Albert Thomas, believed that some of the Black militants were members of the Black Panther Party, however, the Black Panthers denied any involvement in the attacks.  State troopers were ordered into Cairo as a result of the attacks.
scite1: "Armed Negroes Attack Police Station in Cairo, Ill." New York Times, October 25, 1970.
scite2: "State Troopers on Duty in Cairo," New York Times, October 26, 1970.
scite3: "Riflemen Attack Police Station," Deseret News, October 24, 1970.

summary: 10/25/1970: Unknown perpetrators sent a mail bomb that exploded at the main post office in Washington D.C., United States.  The bomb caused no damage to the building, but one person was injured.  Minutes after the explosion, an anonymous phone caller told the post office, apparently unaware that the bomb already detonated, to evacuate the building because there was a bomb.  Authorities were unable to determine who the mailbomb was intended for.
weapdetail: The bomb was wrapped in brown paper and police discovered remnants of black powder, a battery, and a timing device.
propcomment: One bag of mail was destroyed
addnotes: Walter Smith, a post office employee, was treated for shock.
scite1: Henry Aubin and B. D. Colen, "Mail Parcel Explodes in Post Office," Washington Post, October 26, 1970.
scite2: "Package Explodes in D.C. Post Office," Baltimore Sun, October 26, 1970.
scite3: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 10/28/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw five firebombs at the Martin County Courthouse in Stuart, Florida, United States.  Two of the bombs landed inside the building and three of the bombs landed outside the building.  There were no casualties and the building sustained less than $500 in damages.
weapdetail: Five firebombs made out of beer bottles
propcomment: Minor damage to doorway area
addnotes: Authorities believed that the perpetrators were 'hippie-types.'  Some officials suspected that this attack was in response to a proposed ban on drinking liquor at the beach.
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on D
scite2: "Martin Courthouse Firebombed," Palm Beach Post, October 27, 1970.

summary: 10/28/1970: Suspected revolutionary leftists bombed a police car parked at the Whitefish Bay Police Station in Whitefish Bay, Wisconsin, United States.  The blast was coordinated to go off during the middle of a shift change, however there were no casualties.  Two police cars were damaged in the attack.  This incident was believed to be linked to the many bombings in the Milwaukee, Wisconsin area during this time period.
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: Six inch pipe bomb consisting of black power and connected to a pocket watch
propcomment: Gas tank blew up and the resulting fire wrecked the police car and the vehicle next to it
addnotes: Authorities were unsure whether the pipe bomb was placed under a pile of leaves or attached under the gas tank of the vehicle.  Authorities linked the bomb used in this incident with the attempted bombing at Likeside Laboratories in Milwaukee Wisconsin on September 4th (197009040004).  Both bombs were built according to an instruction manual circulated by revolutionaries.  The Whitefish Bay Chief of Police believed that this incident might also be linked with bombs discovered at Whitefish Bay State Bank, Honeywell Inc. and the Wisconsin Motor Division (197006290002, 197007000001, and 197008050001).  There were other bombings in the Milwaukee area during this time period as well (197012220001, 197007220002, and 197007210004).
scite1: Alex P. Dobish, "Bay Offers $2,500 Reward for Squad Car Bomber," Milwaukee Journal, November 3, 1970.
scite2: Edward S. Kerstein, "Bomb Demolishes Police Car in Bay," Milwaukee Journal, October 28, 1970.
scite3: "2 Bombs Tied to Rebel Manual," Milwaukee Journal, November 2, 1970.

summary: 10/29/1970: Two unknown perpetrators threw two Molotov cocktails into the El Toro Marine Corps Air Station in El Toro, California, United States.  The firebombs landed in the motor pool area but caused no damage.
target1: Marine Corps Air Station, El Toro California
motive: To protest the US military
weapdetail: Two thrown Molotov cocktails filled with gasoline
propcomment: Firebombs flared up impacting the ground but caused no damage
addnotes: The two perpetrators threw the firebombs over an eight foot fence.  After launching the Molotov cocktails, they were fired upon by Military Police stationed at the base, but escaped unscathed.
scite1: "El Toro Motor Pool Firebombed; Pair Flee," Los Angeles Times, October 30, 1970.

summary: 10/30/1970: In a series of three related incidents, unknown perpetrators bombed the United States Naval Militia Armory in Queens, New York, United States.  Minutes before the blast, an anonymous caller stated that a bomb was set to go off in the armory in five minutes.  There were no casualties but the building and surrounding area sustained around $7,500 in damages.
target1: United State Naval Militia Armory, Queens New York
weapdetail: Homemade pipe bomb with explosives intended to be used underwater
propcomment: Building damaged and shrapnel riddled the surrounding area
addnotes: This is part of a multiple attack with 197010300002 and 197010300003.  The bomb was placed on the window sill and detonated at 3:12 AM.  Authorities estimated that there were between $5,000 to $10,000 in damages.  Later in the day there was a bomb scare are New York City Hall and a bomb was discovered against a tree stump in the Bronx (197010300004).
scite1: Martin Arnold, "3 Bombs Damage Buildings In City," New York Times, October 31, 1970.
scite2: "Bombs Used in 3 Attacks Differed," New York Times, November 1, 1970.

summary: 10/30/1970: In a series of three related incidents, unknown perpetrators bombed the Police Motorcycle Headquarters in the Bronx, New York, United States.  There were no casualties but two holes were blown into the ceiling of the facility and a window was shattered.
target1: Police Motorcycle Headquarters, the Bronx New York
weapdetail: Homemade pipe bomb containing two propane tanks
propcomment: Window shattered and two holes torn in ceiling
addnotes: This is part of a multiple attack with 197010300001 and 197010300003.  The bomb was placed inside the air conditioner unit and detonated at 3:15 AM.  The bomb was less powerful than those at the National Guard Armories, but it caused more fire damage.  Later in the day there was a bomb scare are New York City Hall and a bomb was discovered against a tree stump in the Bronx (197010300004).
scite1: Martin Arnold, "3 Bombs Damage Buildings In City," New York Times, October 31, 1970.
scite2: "Bombs Used in 3 Attacks Differed," New York Times, November 1, 1970.

target1: Army Reserve Center, Queens New York
weapdetail: Homemade pipe bomb with explosives intended to be used underwater
propcomment: Hole torn into building
addnotes: This is part of a multiple attack with 197010300001 and 197010300002.  The bomb was placed on the window sill and detonated at 3:22 AM.  Later in the day there was a bomb scare are New York City Hall and a bomb was discovered against a tree stump in the Bronx (197010300004).

summary: 10/30/1970: On a day of multiple bombings in New York City, postman Anthony Muranelli discovered two apparent homemade bombs in a bag lying against a tree stump in the Bronx, New York, United States.  He turned the bombs over to the police and they were subsequently disarmed.
weapdetail: Two fifteen inch devices attached to two bottles of gasoline
addnotes: Earlier in the day there was a multiple attack against two National Guard Armories and the Police Motorcycle Headquarters (197010300001, 197010300002, and 197010300003).  On the same day there was also a bomb scare at New York City Hall.
scite1: Martin Arnold, "3 Bombs Damage Buildings In City," New York Times, October 31, 1970.

summary: 11/1/1970: African American Ronald Mitchell was killed in a drive-by shooting by suspected White Racists in New Castle, Pennsylvania, United States.  His death sparked violent race riots throughout the city.
motive: Suspected motive was to intimidate the African American community of New Castle Pennsylvania.
addnotes: This attack directly led to the outbreak of riots by the African American community of New Castle, Pennsylvania.
scite1: "Slaying Spurs Disorders," New York Times, November 2, 1970.
scite2: "Murder of Black Veteran Triggers New Castle Riot," New Pittsburg Courier, November 7, 1970.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 11/1/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed a Navy R.O.T.C. vehicle at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, Michigan, United States.  There were no casualties and it is unknown if the vehicle was damaged.
target1: Navy R.O.T.C. Vehicle, University of Michigan
motive: To protest the R.O.T.C. program
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 11/7/1970: Unknown perpetrators set fire to the Cairo Lumber Company in Cairo, Illinois, United States.  There were no casualties but the fire caused an estimated $100,000 in damages.  The lumber yard was owned by Robert Cunningham, the former leader of a White vigilante group.
motive: This incident, directed against the White community of Cairo, took place during a period of widespread racial disturbances
weapdetail: Kerosene and gasoline lit on fire
propcomment: Lumber yard was destroyed
addnotes: Shortly after this attack, it is suspected that Wiley Anderson was shot and killed by White perpetrators (197011080001).  Robert Cunningham was the former leader of the vigilante group the White Hats.  At the time of the incident, he was the president of the United Citizens for Community Action.
scite1: "Soldier Shot and Lumberyard Burned in Illinois Racial Violence," New York Times, November 9, 1970.
scite2: "Cairo Plant Burns During Racial Clash," Washington Post, November 9, 1970.
scite3: Thomas F. Parker, "Violence in the U.S.: Volume 2, 1968-71," Facts on File, Inc., 1974.

summary: 11/7/1970: Unknown perpetrators ignited a fire in the Air Force Library located within the University of Minnesota Armory in Minneapolis, Minnesota, United States.  There were no casualties and the damages amounted to only $500.
target1: Air Force Library located in the University of Minnesota Armory
motive: To protest the US military
addnotes: The perpetrators cut a screen and entered the facility through a window.
scite1: "Fire Set at Armory at U. of Minnesota," Chicago Tribune, November 8, 1970.
scite2: "The Nation: 5,000 Postmasters to Be Chosen on Merits," Los Angeles Times, November 8, 1970.

summary: 11/8/1970: Shortly after a lumber yard owned by Robert Cunningham, a former leader of a White vigilante group in Cairo, Illinois, United States, was set on fire, Wiley Anderson, an African American, was shot four times as he was walking in the Pyramid Court Housing Projects in Cairo.  Leaders of Cairo's African American community believed that Anderson was shot by White snipers firing indiscriminately into the predominantly Black housing projects.  Anderson died from his wounds two weeks later.
target1: African Americans walking in the Pyramid Court Housing Project in Cairo Illinois
motive: To kill African Americans
addnotes: This incident occurred a short time after the lumber yard of Cairo Illinois was set on fire (197011070002).  Wiley Anderson was a sergeant on leave from the army.  Members of the United Front, an organization directing an African American boycott of White owned business in Cairo, believed that the sniper fire was coming from two different directions.  The United Front also stated that Walter Garrett, who was walking with Wiley Anderson at the time, was also shot.  However, the police dispute this claim.  The FBI stated that there was no evidence that any federal statutes were violated and the police were unsure who shot Wiley Anderson.
scite1: "Cairo Plant Burns During Racial Clash," Washington Post, November 9, 1970.
scite2: "Panther Trial Judge Reverses Ruling, Allows Tapes," Washington Post, December 1, 1970.
scite3: "Cairo Disturbances," Reading Eagle, November 9, 1970.

summary: 11/12/1970: An unknown perpetrator, described as long-haired and bearded, threw three firebombs at the West Side Selective Service office in Chicago, Illinois, United States.  There were no casualties but one of the firebombs smashed through the window causing minor damage to the building.
target1: West Side Selective Service Office, Chicago Illinois
motive: Protest and sabotage the draft
weapdetail: Three brown bottles containing an unknown substance thrown at the building
propcomment: Minor damage to the office
addnotes: One of the firebombs exploded at the rear of the building.
scite1: "Draft Office Fire Bombed," New York Times, November 13, 1970.
scite2: "Draft Office Is Firebombed In Chicago," Washington Post, November 13, 1970.
scite3: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 11/15/1970: Police Officers John B. Horton and George A. Gatchel were beat up by African Americans in St. Petersburg, Florida, United States.  A car driving erratically was used to lure a police patrol car to a parking lot.  When Officers Horton and Gatchel got out of their car, two vehicles filled with ten to fifteen people sped into the lot.  Armed with rocks, bottles, plywood, and sticks the men got out of the car and injured both police officers.  The St. Petersburg Chief of Police  believed that the perpetrators were inspired by the many assaults on policemen by "revolutionary extremists" throughout the United States.
motive: To injure police
weapdetail: Fist, feet, rocks, bottles, sticks, and two-by-two piece of plywood
addnotes: Both officers received injuries to their faces.  Officer Horton required thirteen stitches and officer Gatchel required eight stitches.  Three days later, a White revolutionary firebombed a police car in St. Petersburg and stated his support for the "Black brothers" who beat up the police officers (197011180001).
scite1: Guy Kovner, "2 Policemen Are Beaten," St. Petersburg, November 18, 1970.
scite2: Mike Foley, "3 Arrested At Scene, 2 Policemen Beaten," Evening Independent, November 16, 1970.
scite3: "Two Men Plead Innocent," St. Petersburg, November 21, 1970.

summary: 11/18/1970: Self-proclaimed White Revolutionaries threw a firebomb at Officer Bill Detterline's parked police vehicle at his house in St. Petersburg, Florida, United States.  There were no casualties but the police cruiser was destroyed.  The perpetrators left a note saying that they were showing support for their "Black brothers" in their struggles against the police and that "a revolution has started in the sunshine city." Three days earlier, a group of African Americans attacked two St. Petersburg police officers.
motive: To fight the oppression of African Americans, to attack to police, and to instigate a revolution
propcomment: Officer Detterline's police car was destroyed
addnotes: The perpetrators threw a brick attached with a note at the scene listing their revolutionary motivations for the attack.  The note also referenced the attack on the two policemen three days earlier (197011150002).  The note was signed "Mongoose."  Police believed that Mongoose could have been John Allen Brown, the individual who placed a bomb in the St. Petersburg area four day later (197011220002).
scite1: "'White Revolutionaries' Fire Bomb Police Car," Sarasota Herald-Tribune, November 18, 1970.
scite2: Bill Watson, "Police Car Set Afire," Evening Independent, November 18, 1970.
scite3: "Bomb Plant Probed," Evening Independent, November 23, 1970.

location: The incident occurred at City Hall.
summary: 11/21/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed a replica of the Liberty Bell that was located behind City Hall in Portland, Oregon, United States.  The blast destroyed the bell, damaged the front doors of City Hall, and shattered windows of buildings in the surrounding area.  A janitor was also injured by flying debris.
target1: Replica of Liberty Bell located at Portland City Hall
propcomment: Liberty Bell destroyed, doors of City Hall damaged, furniture in City Hall upended, and windows within a three block radius of the blast were shattered.
addnotes: The bomb detonated at 2:55 AM.  No group claimed responsibility but authorities suspected that the perpetrators were part of the "protest community."
scite1: "Liberty Bell Copy Blown Up," New York Times, November 22, 1970.
scite2: Jim Redden, "Tumultuous Times Fattened the Files," Portland Tribune, October 30, 2009.
scite3: "Portland's City Hall Hit by Blast," Spokane Daily Chronicle, November 21, 1970.

summary: 11/21/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a bomb into the house of L. D. Turner, the chief of security of a TNT manufacturer roiled in a labor dispute.  There were no casualties but Turner's house in Chattanooga, Tennessee, United States sustained extensive damage.
corp1: Chief of security for a Tennessee TNT company in a labor dispute
weapdetail: Four to six sticks of dynamite tossed into the house
propcomment: Every room in house damaged
addnotes: Authorities did not believe that L. D. Turner's house was bombed because his company manufactured TNT for use in Vietnam.
scite1: "Bomb Rips Home of Plant Guard," Los Angeles Times, November 22, 1970.
scite2: "Home, Bell Blasts," St. Petersburg Times, November 22, 1970.

summary: 11/22/1970: John Allen Brown placed a high explosive bomb within the vicinity of the Shore Acre-Snell Isle area of St. Petersburg, Florida, United States.  The bomb failed to explode due to a timing malfunction.  Police believed that Brown might have bombed a police car in St. Petersburg four days earlier.
weapdetail: High explosive bomb with a timing mechanism
addnotes: Police believed that the perpetrator of the attack, John Allen Brown, could have been Mongoose, the individual who firebombed a police car in St. Petersburg four days earlier (197011180001).  The authorities did not release the exact location of where the bomb was discovered.  However, they did say that it would have caused considerable damage.
scite1: "Bomb Plant Probed," Evening Independent, November 23, 1970.

summary: 11/25/1970: An unknown perpetrator placed a bomb in the men's restroom of the gymnasium at the University of California, Berkeley, United States.  The bomb was discovered by a custodian and subsequently disarmed by a military bomb squad.
scite1: "Bomb Found at Berkeley," New York Times, November 27, 1970.
scite2: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on D

summary: 11/25/1970: Two days after the Armed Commandos of Liberation bombed the Consulate of the Dominican Republic, unknown perpetrators placed a bomb in the R.O.T.C. building of the University of Puerto Rico in San Juan, Puerto Rico.  The fragmentation device was discovered and removed thirty minutes before it was set to detonate.
target1: R.O.T.C. building, University of Puerto Rico
motive: Promote Puerto Rican Independence
addnotes: This incident took place two days after the a bombing of the Dominican Consulate in San Juan, Puerto Rico (197011230001).
scite1: "Independence Factions Believed Behind Puerto Rico's Recent Bombings," Washington Post, November 30, 1970.

summary: 12/1/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed Johnson Hall at the University of Oregon in Eugene, Oregon, United States.  There were no casualties but the bomb caused $9,000 in damages.
weapdetail: Four to five sticks of dynamite
propcomment: The office of the high school relations program was damaged and windows in three buildings shattered
addnotes: The bomb was placed outside of a ground level window of Johnson Hall.  The building housed the office of the university president.

scite2: "'68 Mine Tragedy Yields 3 Bodies," Baltimore Sun, December 2, 1970

summary: 12/18/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed a building that housed the draft board in San Mateo, California, United States.  There were no casualties and it is unknown if the building was damaged.

summary: 12/22/1970: A revolutionary leftist bombed National Guard trucks stationed at the Whitefish Bay Armory in Whitefish Bay, Wisconsin, United States.  One truck was damaged but the resulting fire was extinguished before it had a chance to spread to the thirty other vehicles parked at the lot.  There were many other bombings in the Milwaukee, Wisconsin area during this time period.
target1: Trucks at the Whitefish Bay Armory
motive: Protest the national guard and the US military
weapdetail: Four inch pipe bomb connected to a watch
propcomment: Ten inch hole in the top of the gas tank
addnotes: The bomb went off at 1:30 AM.  The perpetrator cut through a fence to sneak into the facilities.  The bomb was placed above the gas tank of the truck, but the tank did not explode.  However, some fuel did catch on fire.  This was one of many bombings and attempted bombings that took place in the Milwaukee Wisconsin area during a five month period. (197010280002, 197007220002, 197009040004, 197006290002, 197007000001, 197008050001, and 197007210004).
scite1: Alex P. Dobish, "Bay Bomb Suspect Leaves Footprints," Milwaukee Journal, December 22, 1970.
scite2: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 12/27/1970:  James Palmer Brewer and Randy Gerald Davis placed a bomb wrapped in a paper bag in front of the Army Recruiting Station in College Park, Georgia, United States.  A janitor was injured picking up the bomb and glass windows and doors were shattered.
target1: Army Recruiting Station, College Park Georgia
motive: To protest and sabotage the US Military
weapdetail: Bomb consisted of around a quarter pound of black powder that was detonated by two batteries
propcomment: Glass door and windows shattered at the recruiting station and a nearby building
addnotes: Six weeks later, James Palmer Brewer and Randy Gerald Davis bombed an Armed Forces Induction Center in Atlanta, Georgia (197102130001).  Brewer was a soldier who had gone  AWOL.  Luther Grier, a janitor, was burned and cut.
scite1: "Bomb Damages Ga. Recruiting Office," Washington Post, December 29, 1971.
scite2: "Bomb Blast Injured Janitor At Army Office in Georgia," New York Times, December 29, 1971.
scite3: "Federal Grand Jury Indicts Two," Herald Journal, February 10, 1972.

summary: 12/31/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed the municipal court building in El Monte, California, United States.  There were no casualties but a door of the building was destroyed and twelve windows were shattered.

summary: 1/1/1971: The Mount Gilead, North Carolina, United States garage of William Chambers, the father of civil rights attorney Julius Chambers, was suspected to have been destroyed by arson.  There were no casualties  but the damages to building were estimated to be $11,000.

motive: To intimidate Julius Chambers from representing causes of the civil rights movement.
addnotes: There was a fire at the garage five months earlier that was not considered an arson attack.  This attack is linked with 197102040002.
scite1: "Arson Seen in 2nd NC Garage Fire," Afro-American, January 23, 1971.

propcomment: Drapes, carpet, windows, and sound equipment damaged

summary: 1/6/1971: Unknown perpetrators threw a firebomb into the Camp Fire Girls Headquarters in Pomona, California, United States.  There were no casualties, however, the building was destroyed causing an estimated $50,000 in damages.  This attack occurred during heightened racial tensions in Pomona which included an attempted boycott of the school system.
target1: Camp Fire Girls Headquarters in Pomona
motive: To protest the Pomona California school system
weapdetail: A firebomb was thrown through a window of the building.
propcomment: The building was destroyed
addnotes: This attack took place during heightened racial tensions in Pomona, California.  Police believed that this attack might have been linked with racial disturbances (197101090001, 197101090002, and 197101110003) at Pomona High School where a  boycott by Black students was in the process of being implemented.
scite1: "Firebomb Causes $50,000 Damage," Washington Post, January 7, 1971.
scite2: "Pomona Tension Goes On," Los Angeles Sentinel, January 14, 1971.

summary: 1/9/1971: Unknown perpetrators set a fire in the cafeteria at Garey High School in Pomona, California, United States.  There were no casualties but the fire caused an estimated $15,000 in damages.  This attack occurred during heightened racial tensions in Pomona which included an attempted boycott of the school system.
motive: To protest the Pomona California school system
addnotes: This attack took place during heightened racial tensions in Pomona, California.  At the time, Black students were in the process of implementing a boycott of the school system.  Police believed that this attack was connected with other racial disturbances in Pomona (197101060001, 197101090002, and 197101110003).  As a result of the attacks the schools closed down for a week.
scite1: "Pomona Tension Goes On," Los Angeles Sentinel, January 14, 1971.

motive: To protest the Pomona California school system
propcomment: The fire caused minor damage.

Police believed that this attack was connected with other racial disturbances in Pomona (197101060001, 197101090001, and 197101110003).  As a result of the attacks the schools closed down for a week.

summary: 1/11/1971: Unknown perpetrators set a fire in the cafeteria at Hamilton Elementary School in Pomona, California, United States. summary: 1/19/1971: Unknown perpetrators bombed a Housing Authority Police Station in San Francisco, California, United States.  There were no casualties but about thirty windows were shattered and power and communication lines were knocked out.
target1: Housing Authority Police Station, San Francisco
propcomment: Hole blown into wood structure, around thirty windows shattered, power and communication lines put out of service
addnotes: The bomb was placed behind the police station and some believed that it might have been directed at the power and communication lines.  The police station was located in a predominately African American neighborhood.  Another bomb was discovered at a federal building in San Francisco two hours later (197101190002).
scite1: "Police Station Is Damaged By Bomb in San Francisco," Washington Post, January 21, 1971.
scite2: "Time Bomb Defused at S.F. Military Office," Los Angeles Times, January 21, 1971.
scite3: "Bomber Strikes Police Station," Pittsburgh Press, January 20, 1971.

summary: 1/19/1971: Unknown perpetrators placed a time bomb adjacent to military recruiting offices housed in the old federal building at the San Francisco Civic Center in California, United States.  The bomb was discovered and defused.
target1: Building housing the Army, Air Force, and Marine recruiting offices in San Francisco
addnotes: A Housing Authority Police Station in San Francisco was bombed two hours earlier (197101190001).
scite1: "Police Station Is Damaged By Bomb in San Francisco," Washington Post, January 21, 1971.
scite2: "Time Bomb Defused at S.F. Military Office," Los Angeles Times, January 21, 1971.
scite3: "Bomber Strikes Police Station," Pittsburgh Press, January 20, 1971.

summary: 1/19/1971: Unknown perpetrators firebombed the home of James Ford in Cleveland, Ohio, United States.  There were no casualties but Ford's home sustained $15,000 in damages.  Ford was an administrator at the Cuyahoga Metropolitan Housing Authority.  At the time, dissident employees of the organization were on strike.
corp1: Home of an official of the Cuyahoga Metropolitan Authority
motive: Protest the actions of the Cuyahoga Metropolitan Housing Authority
propcomment: House damaged
addnotes: James Ford was the assistant director of the Carvel Outhwaite public housing project.  Dissident employees were protesting the firing of the program's former housing director.
scite1: "Police Station Is Damaged By Bomb in San Francisco," Washington Post, January 21, 1971.

summary: 1/24/1971: At around 8:00 AM, a member of the Black Liberation Army flagged down a police officer driving his radio car in Manhattan, New York, United States.  When the cop pulled over, the perpetrator began stabbing the officer with a knife.  The officer then shot and killed the assailant.  That morning, the New York Times received two anonymous calls stating that a New York policeman would be killed at 8:00 AM unless the BLA received $100,000.
motive: To kill police
addnotes: The police officer recovered from his stab wounds.  Josh Smith, a man purporting to be from the Black Liberation Army, called New York Channel 7 after the incident claiming that "no longer will the pig hatchet men plant their heels on our people."  He stated that the next two people to be targeted would be the commissioner and deputy commissioner of the New York Police Department.
scite1: Robert Daley, "Target Blue," Delacorte Press, 1973.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 1/26/1971: Unknown perpetrators bombed the boiler room located at the north campus of Twin Lakes High School in West Palm Beach, Florida, United States.  The explosion caused $10,000 in damages to the heating system.  Twin Lakes High School was the scene of intense racial conflict.
target1: Boiler room at the north campus of Twin Lakes High School
motive: To protest the appointment of a White principal at a predominantly African American school
weapdetail: Dynamite connected to a clock device
propcomment: Heating system damaged
addnotes: The bomb was similar to the device used in the attack on principal of Twin Lakes High School two weeks later (197102090002).  There were many instances of racial strife at the high school, and, two weeks before the incident, a white person was appointed principal of the district, despite the recommendations of a biracial committee.
scite1: "Timing Device Fails in Car Blast Attempt," Sarasota Herald-Tribune, February 10, 1971.
scite2: "Dynamite Tied Under Car," St. Petersburg Times, February 10, 1971.

summary: 2/4/1971: The Charlotte, North Carolina, United States law offices of civil rights attorney Julius Chambers were destroyed by arson.  There were no casualties in the attack.
motive: To intimidate Julius Chambers from representing causes of the civil rights movement.
weapdetail: Investigators believed that the fire was set by a chemical.
propcomment: The building was destroyed.
addnotes: The NAACP pledged to assist Chambers rebuild his law offices.  This attack is linked with 197101010001.
scite1: "A Rights Office Burned in South," New York Times, November 5, 1971.
scite2: "Lawyer's Office Burned; NAACP Pledges Help," New Journal and Guide, February 13, 1971.
scite3: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 2/9/1971: Unknown perpetrators placed a bomb underneath the car of Thomas H. Abbott, the principal of Twin Lakes High School in West Palm Beach, Florida, United States.  The bomb failed to explode because the timing device of the weapon malfunctioned.  Twin Lakes High School was the scene of intense racial conflict.
target1: Principal of Twin Lakes High School
corp2: White principal of a predominantly African American high school
motive: To protest the appointment of a White principal at a predominantly African American school
weapdetail: Six sticks of dynamite connected to a clock and a battery
addnotes: The bomb was similar to the device used in a bombing at Twin Lakes High School two weeks earlier (197101260001).  The car of the Palm Beach County's Superintendent was bombed three months later (197105120002).  There were many instances of racial strife at the high school, and, one month before the incident, a white person was appointed principal of the district, despite the recommendations of a biracial committee.  The bomb was set explode at 3:00 PM but the timing device malfunctioned.
scite1: "Timing Device Fails in Car Blast Attempt," Sarasota Herald-Tribune, February 10, 1971.
scite2: "Dynamite Tied Under Car," St. Petersburg Times, February 10, 1971.

summary: 2/10/1971: Charles Lawrence, a member of a Neo-Nazi group, placed a dynamite bomb at the home of Ben Maidenburg in Akron, Ohio, United States.  Maidenburg was the publisher of the Akron Beacon Journal.  The bomb was discovered and subsequently removed.
target2: Home of the publisher of the Akron Beacon Journal
motive: To protest the reporting of the Akron Beacon Journal
weapdetail: Four sticks of dynamite connected to a clock
addnotes: The bomb was set to detonate at 8:30 PM but was discovered four hours earlier.  Charles Lawrence was an organizer for the National Socialist White People's Party.  Ben Maidenburg's house was bombed seven months earlier by an unknown perpetrator (197007040004).
scite1: "Neo-Nazi Accused of Placing Bomb at Publisher's Home," New York Times, March 18, 1971.
scite2: "Bomb Left At Home of Publisher," Washington Post, February 12, 1971.
scite3: "Arrest Follows Kidnap Threat To Publisher," Sarasota Herald-Tribune, March 6, 1974.

location: The incident occurred at Ponce De Leon Ave.
summary: 2/13/1971: James Palmer Brewer and Randy Gerald Davis bombed the Armed Forces Induction Center in Atlanta, Georgia, United States.  There were no casualties but the blast shattered hundreds of windows.
motive: To protest and sabotage the US Military
propcomment: Hundreds of windows shattered at the induction center and surrounding buildings
addnotes: Six weeks earlier James Palmer Brewer and Randy Gerald Davis bombed an Army Recruiting Station in College Park, Georgia (197012270001).  Brewer was a soldier who had gone  AWOL.  The bomb was placed outside of the main doors of the building and detonated shortly before 5:00 AM.  The induction center was also the 81st Army Reserve Command Headquarters.
scite1: "Stanford Suspends Activist Professor," Washington Post, February 14, 1971.
scite2: "Federal Grand Jury Indicts Two," Herald Journal, February 10, 1972.
scite3: "Blast Shakes Induction Center," Times Daily, February 14, 1971.

summary: 2/14/1971: Five anti-war protesters broke into the Bucks County Selective Service office in Bristol, Pennsylvania, United States.  The perpetrators set fire to draft records and ransacked the office.  The interior of the office was heavily damaged and around half of the files were destroyed.
target1: Selective Service office Local Boards No. 35 and no. 335 in Bristol Pennsylvania
motive: To protest the War in Vietnam and the draft
weapdetail: Fire ignited with a flammable substance and files ransacked
propcomment: Over twenty thousand draft records destroyed and the interior of the office was badly damaged
addnotes: The perpetrators sawed there way into the office and the fire was ignited at 12:03 AM on February 15.  The perpetrators stated that they were influenced by the anti-war actions of Philip and Daniel Berrigan.
scite1: "National Can Co., Steel Union Settle," Washington Post, February 16, 1971.
scite2: "Tate Jurors Freed From Confinement," Washington Post, February 17, 1971.
scite3: "Draft Board Office Fire Being Probed," Gettysburg Times, February 16, 1971.

summary: 2/16/1971: In a series of related incidents, Puerto Rican nationalists bombed El San Juan Hotel in San Juan, Puerto Rico.  There were no casualties but the hotel sustained $5,500 in damages.
motive: To protest United States establishments in Puerto Rico
propcomment: Doors broken and windows shattered
addnotes: This is part of multiple attack with 197102160002.  This might also be part of a multiple attack with the three other bombs and incendiary devices discovered at American establishments in Puerto Rico on the same day (197102160003, 197102160004, and 197102160005).  The bomb in this incident detonated near the hotel swimming pool.
scite1: "Tourists Flee Bomb Blasts in San Juan Hotels," Washington Post, February 18, 1971.
scite2: "Bombs Blast Two Hotels In San Juan," The Virgin Islands Daily News, February 18, 1971.
scite3: "Toward People's War for Independence and Socialism in Puerto Rico: In Defense of Armed Struggle," Documents and Communiqués from the Revolutionary Public Independence Movement and the Armed Clandestine Movement, January 1987.

summary: 2/16/1971: In a series of related incidents, Puerto Rican nationalists bombed the Americana in San Juan, Puerto Rico.  There were no casualties but the hotel sustained $5,000 in damages.
motive: To protest United States establishments in Puerto Rico
propcomment: Doors broken and windows shattered
addnotes: This is part of multiple attack with 197102160001.  This might also be part of a multiple attack with the three other bombs and incendiary devices discovered at American establishments in Puerto Rico on the same day (197102160003, 197102160004, and 197102160005).  The bomb in this incident detonated near the hotel swimming pool.
scite1: "Tourists Flee Bomb Blasts in San Juan Hotels," Washington Post, February 18, 1971.
scite2: "Bombs Blast Two Hotels In San Juan," The Virgin Islands Daily News, February 18, 1971.
scite3: "Toward People's War for Independence and Socialism in Puerto Rico: In Defense of Armed Struggle," Documents and Communiqués from the Revolutionary Public Independence Movement and the Armed Clandestine Movement, January 1987.

summary: 2/16/1971: In a series of five incidents that might have been related, Puerto Rican nationalists placed a pipe bomb at the United States Coast Guard radio beacon tower in San Juan, Puerto Rico.  The bomb was discovered and deactivated two hours before it was set to detonate.
target1: United States Coast Guard radio beacon tower in San Juan Puerto Rico
target2: United States Coast Guard radio beacon tower in San Juan Puerto Rico
motive: To protest United States presence in Puerto Rico
weapdetail: A timed pipe bomb was used in the attack.
scite1: "Tourists Flee Bomb Blasts in San Juan Hotels," Washington Post, February 18, 1971.
scite2: "Bombs Blast Two Hotels In San Juan," The Virgin Islands Daily News, February 18, 1971.

summary: 2/16/1971: In a series of five incidents that might have been related, Puerto Rican nationalists placed three Molotov cocktails in an office building housing American owned businesses in San Juan, Puerto Rico.  The firebombs were discovered unignited and subsequently removed.
corp1: American owned business in Puerto Rico
target1: Office building housing American businesses in the Old City of San Juan
motive: To protest United States owned businesses in Puerto Rico
scite1: "Tourists Flee Bomb Blasts in San Juan Hotels," Washington Post, February 18, 1971.
scite2: "Bombs Blast Two Hotels In San Juan," The Virgin Islands Daily News, February 18, 1971.

summary: 2/16/1971: In a series of five incidents that might have been related, Puerto Rican nationalists placed an incendiary device in the Franklin's Store in Rio Piedras, Puerto Rico.  The firebomb were discovered unignited and subsequently removed.
corp1: American owned business in Puerto Rico
motive: To protest United States owned businesses in Puerto Rico
addnotes: This might be part of a multiple attack with the four other bombings and attempted bombings of American establishments in Puerto Rico on the same day (197102160001, 197102160002, 197102160003, and 197102160004).  The incendiary device in this incident was discovered between clothing in the children's department of the store.
scite1: "Tourists Flee Bomb Blasts in San Juan Hotels," Washington Post, February 18, 1971.
scite2: "Bombs Blast Two Hotels In San Juan," The Virgin Islands Daily News, February 18, 1971.

summary: 2/20/1971: Miami Police Officer Victor Butler Jr. was ambushed by suspected members of the Black Afro-militant Movement (BAMM) in Miami, Florida, United States.  The bullets struck him in the chest and back and he died instantly.  BAMM members John Lane and John Murray Johnson were indicted of the murder but the charges were dropped when the police witness, and fellow BAMM member Jan Thurston, recanted his confession.  Police eventually indicted Thurston for the murder but charges against him were also dropped because a judged ruled that he was questioned without probable cause.
motive: To promote violence against the establishment
addnotes: Victor Butler was an African American.  In his original confession, Thurston stated that he was in a car with 3-5 people that dropped Lane and Johnson off to commit the murder.  The Miami Police Department considers the case closed since Lane, Johnson, and Thurston, who the department believed to be involved in the incident, were arrested.
scite1: Dr. William Wilbanks, "Forgotten Heroes: Police Officers Killed in Dade County," Turner Publishing Company, 1996.

summary: 2/22/1970:  A realty office in Los Angeles, California, United States was bombed by the Chicano Liberation Front.  Apparently the office was mistakenly thought to be owned by a critic of militant Chicanos.  There were no casualties.
motive: To intimidate critics of the Chicano Liberation Front.
addnotes: The realty office that was bombed was apparently mistaken for an office that was owned by a critic of the Chicano Liberation Front.  On the outside of the wall of the office, "Chicano Liberation Front" was written with shoe polish.
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 2/26/1971: Unknown perpetrators set fire to the R.O.T.C. building at the University of Hawaii, in Honolulu, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained $70,000 in damages.
motive: To protest the R.O.T.C. program
propcomment: Wooden building destroyed
addnotes: A week later, another building on the University of Hawaii campus was set on fire, however, authorities did not believe that this incident was carried out by the same perpetrators (197103050001).
scite1: Lester A. Sobel, "Political Terrorism," Facts on File, Inc., 1975.
scite2: "Security Boosted At University After 2 Fires," Hartford Courant, March 7, 1971.
scite3: "Blaze Destroys R.O.T.C. Buildings," Modesto Bee, February 25, 1971.

summary: 2/27/1971: Unknown perpetrators placed a bomb in a Selective Service office in Rio Piedras, Puerto Rico.  It is unknown if the bomb detonated.
motive: To protest the draft and United States presence in Puerto Rico
addnotes: Authorities suspected that the perpetrators of this incident might have participated in campus riots at the University of Puerto Rico two weeks later.
scite1: Martin Arnold, "San Juan Rioting and Bomb Studied," New York Times, March 16, 1971.
scite2: "Toward People's War for Independence and Socialism in Puerto Rico: In Defense of Armed Struggle," Documents and Communiqués from the Revolutionary Public Independence Movement and the Armed Clandestine Movement, January 1987.

summary: 3/5/1971: Unknown perpetrators set a travel industry management school building on fire at the University of Hawaii in Honolulu, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained an estimated $7,500 in damages.
target1: Travel industry management school building, University of Hawaii
weapdetail: Fire caused by gasoline splashed around the building
propcomment: Two offices scorched and the building sustained water damage
addnotes: A week earlier, the R.O.T.C. building at the University of Hawaii campus was destroyed by fire, however, authorities did not believe that this incident was carried out by the same perpetrators (197102260002).  A broken bottleneck with a wick and matchbook were discovered at the scene.
scite1: Lester A. Sobel, "Political Terrorism," Facts on File, Inc., 1975.
scite2: "Security Boosted At University After 2 Fires," Hartford Courant, March 7, 1971.

location: The incident occurred at New Town Church.
summary: 3/6/1971: In a series of related events, unknown perpetrators firebombed the predominantly Black Mount Orange Baptist Church in Texarkana, Texas, United States.  There were no casualties but the Church was completely destroyed.
motive: Two different motives suspected.  Either Black radicals punishing the Churches for not allowing expelled Black students to temporarily use their facilities for classes or White racists trying to intimidate the African American community of Texarkana Texas.
propcomment: The church was destroyed.
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197103060002, 197103070001, and 197103070002. This incident took place during heightened racial tensions in Texarkana Texas after a large fight between Black and White students.  Leaders of the Black community were unsure whether the attack was carried out by White Racists or Black radicals.  Many Blacks were disappointed that the Churches did not open up their facilities for the 126 Black students expelled as a result of the fight.  Black officials were afraid to speculate the identities of the perpetrators because they feared more reprisals.
scite1: Homar Bigart, "Burned Churches Rebuilt in Texas," New York Times, June 21, 1972.
scite2: "Four Black Churches Fire Bombed in Texas," Jet Magazine, March 25, 1971.
scite3: "Bomb in Negro Church," New York Times, March 8, 1971.

location: The incident occurred at New Town Church.
summary: 3/6/1971: In a series of related events, unknown perpetrators firebombed the predominantly Black St. Paul's Baptist Church in Texarkana, Texas, United States.  There were no casualties but the Church was completely destroyed.
motive: Two different motives suspected.  Either Black radicals punishing the Churches for not allowing expelled Black students to temporarily use their facilities for classes or White racists trying to intimidate the African American community of Texarkana Texas.
propcomment: The church was destroyed.
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197103060001, 197103070001, and 197103070002.This incident took place during heightened racial tensions in Texarkana Texas after a large fight between Black and White students.  Leaders of the Black community were unsure whether the attack was carried out by White Racists or Black radicals.  Many Blacks were disappointed that the Churches did not open up their facilities for the 126 Black students expelled as a result of the fight.  Black officials were afraid to speculate the identities of the perpetrators because they feared more reprisals.
scite1: Homar Bigart, "Burned Churches Rebuilt in Texas," New York Times, June 21, 1972.
scite2: "Four Black Churches Fire Bombed in Texas," Jet Magazine, March 25, 1971.
scite3: "Bomb in Negro Church," New York Times, March 8, 1971.

location: The incident occurred at New Town Church.
summary: 3/7/1971: In a series of related events, unknown perpetrators attempted to firebomb the predominantly Black New Town Church in Texarkana, Texas, United States.  The firebomb malfunctioned and the church sustained no damages.
motive: Two different motives suspected.  Either Black radicals punishing the Churches for not allowing expelled Black students to temporarily use their facilities for classes or White racists trying to intimidate the African American community of Texarkana Texas.
weapdetail: The firebomb sputtered but failed to explode
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197103060001, 197103060002,and 197103070002. This incident took place during heightened racial tensions in Texarkana Texas after a large fight between Black and White students.  Leaders of the Black community were unsure whether the attack was carried out by White Racists or Black radicals.  Many Blacks were disappointed that the Churches did not open up their facilities for the 126 Black students expelled as a result of the fight.  Black officials were afraid to speculate the identities of the perpetrators because they feared more reprisals.
scite1: Homar Bigart, "Burned Churches Rebuilt in Texas," New York Times, June 21, 1972.
scite2: "Four Black Churches Fire Bombed in Texas," Jet Magazine, March 25, 1971.
scite3: "Bomb in Negro Church," New York Times, March 8, 1971.

location: The incident occurred at New Town Church.
summary: 3/7/1971: In a series of related events, unknown perpetrators firebombed the predominantly Black Holy Chapel church in Texarkana, Texas, United States.  There were no casualties and the church sustained minor damages.
motive: Two different motives suspected.   Either Black radicals punishing the Churches for not allowing expelled Black students to temporarily use their facilities for classes or White racists trying to intimidate the African American community of Texarkana Texas.
propcomment: The pulpit was burnt.
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197103060001, 197103060002, and 197103070001. This incident took place during heightened racial tensions in Texarkana Texas after a large fight between Black and White students.  Leaders of the Black community were unsure whether the attack was carried out by White Racists or Black radicals.  Many Blacks were disappointed that the Churches did not open up their facilities for the 126 Black students expelled as a result of the fight.  Black officials were afraid to speculate the identities of the perpetrators because they feared more reprisals.
